In this video, Dr. Golly will encourage you to make a mess! Introducing solids is meant to be fun, exploratory, messy, and silly. If you are anxious about what your baby is eating, how much they are eating, and what mess is being madeâ€”then your baby is far less likely to develop a positive association with solids.

In this video, Dr. Golly will talk you through the signs of developmental readiness for solids, the best way to introduce new foods, the importance of reducing allergy risk, and ways to make solids lead to better day and night sleep. Follow these steps, and Dr. Golly will have your baby sleeping 12 hours straight in no time!

Lesson Name: Signs of Readiness to Start Solids
Lesson Content:
Signs your baby is ready to start solids include:

  • More frequent night waking and catnapping during the day
  • Your baby watching you more intently when you are eating and seeming more interested
  • Reaching for food as you try to eat
  • Putting objects in their mouth more often

Babies do NOT need trunk control (i.e., sitting independently) to be able to start solids. They only need head control and can be safely fed in a â€˜fittedâ€™ high-chair, bouncer, parentâ€™s lap, etc.

Remember, solids at this stage are considered â€˜complementsâ€™ to milk, not replacements. Breast milk or formula is still the most important part of their nutritional intake, so this is an opportunity for baby and parents to learn about different smells, textures, and flavors.

Order to introduce solids

This following order isnâ€™t set in stone, and every family should do what is right for them. However, I recommend starting with one meal and, once established, quickly introducing another.

  1. Introduce lunch first â€“ It is often the least stressful time of day, and you have more time to observe any reactions your baby might have to a particular food.
  2. Introduce dinner â€“ After a few days of offering lunch.
  3. Introduce breakfast â€“ Once lunch and dinner have been established for a couple of weeks.

Separating solids from milk

Try to separate solids from milk (and vice versa) by 30-40 minutes to help generate an appetite. For the 4-6 month age group, milk should still be offered before solids since it provides the bulk of nutrition. However, a milk/solids/milk combination can work for some babies.

From 6-7 months, offering solids before milk at lunchtime can encourage more interest in eating. A big milk feed beforehand can reduce hunger for solids.

What types of food to start with

Start with purees of fruits and vegetables such as:

  • Sweet potato
  • Pumpkin
  • Carrot
  • Peas
  • Zucchini
  • Pear
  • Apple
  • Banana and avocado (these donâ€™t require cooking to puree)

Be cautious with foods that may cause gas, like cauliflower and broccoli. Iron-fortified infant cereal is also a great first food, especially for vegetarian families since plant-based iron sources are high in fiber and need to be introduced gradually.

Introduce NEW foods regularly

Introduce one new food at a time before combining different flavors. Offer both purees/mashed foods and finger foods to help babies learn how to manage different textures. The goal is to expose your baby to as many flavors and textures as possible while monitoring for potential allergic reactions.

Lots of parents love a list to tick off â€“ Keeping track of foods introduced can be helpful, especially if multiple caregivers are involved in feeding. If this sounds like you see my checklist below.

Gagging

Gagging is normal and indicates that the baby is protecting their airway by moving food that isnâ€™t going down correctly. Parents anxious about choking may feel more comfortable offering new textures in the presence of another parent, family member, or support person. This way, they donâ€™t delay introducing textures but still feel reassured.

Baby-led weaning

Baby-led weaning is an approach where babies skip purees and go straight to small solids they manipulate and self-feed. Since this method requires certain developmental abilities, babies may not consume adequate solid volumes until 8-9 months.

It's important to follow each baby's lead and use a mix of traditional feeding and baby-led weaning. Encourage both pureed feeding and independent exploration of textures while ensuring close supervision, updated first aid knowledge, and a willingness to embrace the mess!

Once your baby is 6 months old introducing protein at lunchtime will help stabilise their blood sugars overnight and help reduce night wake ups. 25-50g of a protein source should be added, these include foods like chicken, turkey, red meats, fish, egg and dairy.

PLEASE NOTE: this recommendation is not at the micro nutrient level of protein you read on a food label - it's 25-50g of a protein source so just add 25-50g of your protein source of choice to their meal. e.g. 25-50g of chicken breast blended with pumpkin. What lots of families do is make simple 2-3 ingredient combos like this and freeze them in portions so it's easy to access everyday.

Prioritising protein at lunchtime is important as from 6 months of age a baby's protein requirements increase from what breastmilk and formula alone can provide. Protein can also be added to breakfast from this age too. 

From my experience protein shouldnâ€™t be offered at dinner time until closer to 8-9 months as it can affect digestion overnight. However this doesn't affect all babies and if your baby is fine with protein at dinner you can continue to offer it.

Beans and legumes are a great source of protein but shouldnâ€™t be offered until closer to 8 months old as they can make babies quite windy. Itâ€™s also very important to include iron rich foods from this age group as around 6 months is when your babyâ€™s iron stores start to deplete, so including meat in their diet (in particular lamb) gives your baby the benefits of a protein and iron rich source.


Ready-made baby pouches available from supermarkets are a quick and convenient option, however be aware that the amount of protein in them is minimal, and your baby is unlikely getting enough protein if just offered these.

Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that serves several important purposes, like nitrogen balance in adults and growth in infants. It also creates niacin, which is essential in creating the neurotransmitter serotonin which is converted to melatonin in the presence of darkness. 

Melatonin is our sleep hormone so a healthy production of this is important.

Foods high in tryptophan include turkey, chicken, bananas, oats, kidney beans, dairy and eggs and adding these to your childâ€™s diet can encourage healthy sleep. Bear in mind though that kidney beans may make some babies windy so it is best to wait until closer to 8/9 months to offer these.

Remember that constipation refers to the content of the poo, not the frequency.

If your baby passes a soft bowel action, even as infrequently as weekly, this is not constipation. Sometimes babies simply find it difficult to coordinate the muscle changes required to pass a poo. When this occurs, your baby may show signs of discomfort, and you can help them focus their attention on their bottom (anus) by using the spike of a twisted tissue to â€˜tickleâ€™ their anus while they try to push.

Iron-rich foods and the commencement of solids can sometimes lead to constipation in babies. Many formula brands also suggest switching to â€˜stage 2â€™ versions to increase the iron content. It is perfectly safe to remain on newborn/starter versions of common formula brands, especially if flow-on versions are causing constipation.

Sometimes constipation simply happens because a childâ€™s solids intake increases rapidly, and their digestive system isnâ€™t quite ready to digest all of that. Other times, it can be caused by inadequate fibre or fluids. It can also be caused by excessive fructose intake. If the constipation coincides with the introduction of specific foods (e.g., yoghurt in a breastfed baby), then it can sometimes be a residual intolerance to cowâ€™s milk protein.

I recommend a balance of foods, not just focusing on one food group, and ensuring that there is adequate fluid intake.

Cooled, boiled water should be introduced when children start on solids.

Just like all other foods, it can take some time to figure out how to drink water as it has a different viscosity than breast milk or infant formula. I encourage water to be offered in a sippy cup of some sort (lots of parents like the straw cups), but I recommend trying a few different sippy cups to find the one that suits the child best. As dexterity improves, you'll move towards an open cupâ€”get ready for all the splashes and spills!

If constipation is still an issue for your baby, then please see your doctor or paediatrician.

Lesson Name: How Much Solid Food Should My Baby Be Eating?
Lesson Content:
Many books suggest giving your baby a certain amount for their solids meal, however...

A baby will ALWAYS let you know when they have had enough and are no longer interested.

When your baby is no longer interested, they will:

  • Turn away
  • Purse their lips
  • Become irritable and cranky

When they are showing you these signs, donâ€™t keep offering food. Just try again the next day.

I always suggest feeding to appetite. The parent decides what solids and when, but the child decides how much. This applies at 4 months and at 14 years too!

TIP: Always offer meals at least 1 hour before nap or bedtime, as we donâ€™t want your baby going to bed uncomfortable on a very full tummy.

Q: Since starting solids, my baby has reduced their milk intake. Do you recommend cutting out a meal or decreasing the solids offered?

A: This isn't a worry and can be quite normal. The calories and nutrients are now being replaced by food rather than milk. I don't recommend cutting out a meal, as long as your baby is sleeping consistently, is happy during the day, and meeting developmental milestones.

A note before you start reading. As we learned in the starting solids video & content - starting solids should be a fun process that both parents and babies enjoy.

The aim of the following two chapters:

  1. Introducing allergens
  2. Identifying allergic reactions

Is to:

  • Empower you as parents
  • Utilize the latest research and findings to guide you on the best approach to minimize the risk of an allergic reaction
  • Understand if youâ€™re in a potentially higher risk category
  • Know how to identify an allergic reaction
  • Know what to do next if your baby does show signs of a reaction

These chapters are not meant to make you fearful of starting solids andI definitely donâ€™t want to over-medicalize the introduction of solids.Remember thereâ€™s a 90% chance there will be absolutely no problem whatsoever.

With that saidâ€¦

Allergies are on the rise:
Food allergies are on the rise in developed countries, with significant public health impact. Serious allergy (anaphylaxis) can greatly hinder the quality of life for both children and parents.

What are the most common allergens?
The 4 most common dietary allergies are to:

  • Cowâ€™s milk
  • Egg
  • Peanut
  • Tree nuts including cashew, walnut, and pistachio

The next 5 in the cohort are still common compared to other food groups but far less so than the top 4, these are:

  • Fish
  • Shellfish
  • Wheat
  • Soy
  • Sesame

Most children will outgrow allergies to egg, milk, soy, and wheat - but itâ€™s less likely theyâ€™ll grow out of allergies to nuts and seafood - though these may decrease in severity over time.

Common Allergens Image:


When should I introduce allergens?

  • Advice from ASCIA (the allergy governing body) recommends introducing complementary foods (including allergens) in the window of 4-6 months.
  • Introducing allergens in the 4-6 month window is associated with the lowest incidence of allergy for children.
  • Between 4-6 months, single-ingredient infant foods may be introduced, typically including fruits (apples, pears, and bananas), vegetables (green vegetables, sweet potatoes, squash, and carrots), and cereal grains (rice or oat cereal) one at a time.
  • Food can be introduced this way every 3 to 5 days as appropriate for the infantâ€™s developmental readiness.
  • This slow process of introducing new foods and allergens one at a time gives parents or caregivers a chance to identify and eliminate any food that causes an allergic reaction.
  • Egg, dairy, peanut, tree nuts, fish, shellfish, and wheat can be gradually introduced during the same four to six-month window after less allergenic foods have been tolerated.
  • While the 4-6 month window is preferable, donâ€™t stress if you donâ€™t get them all in by 6 months to the day - all allergens should be introduced before your baby turns 12 months.

Never rub food on your baby's skin:
Never rub food on your babyâ€™s skin, especially in babies with eczema, as this may increase the chance of your baby developing a food allergy. Always wash your hands after eating if your baby has eczema. Effective eczema management is one of the key ways we can reduce food allergies, so if your baby is suffering, seek help and treatment immediately.

Don't delay allergen introduction:
Delaying the introduction of these foods may increase your babyâ€™s risk of developing allergies.

Honey should be avoided until 12 months of age:
Not for reasons of allergy, but due to the possibility of contamination with botulinum toxin - botox, which can be found in honey.

How to introduce allergens:

  1. If youâ€™ve chosen peanuts to focus on, for example - get some smooth peanut butter and have your child lick it off your finger or a small spoon. For allergen exposure, they donâ€™t need to swallow and ingest the food - they only need to have it in and around their mouth. Even if they spit it out - consider this enough of an exposure.
    TIP: Make sure youâ€™re not exposing them right before bed - because you want to have an eye on them to note any potential allergic reactions.
  2. Repeat this exposure for a further 2 days.
  3. Once 3 exposures have been successful, you can then intermittently incorporate that food into your babyâ€™s diet and be reassured.
  4. Then move on to the next allergen on your list.
  5. â€‹Once you have tested an allergen, keep it in their diet:
    Once you have fed your baby the common allergy-causing foods, it is important to continue to include these foods in your babyâ€™s meals at least twice a week. Trying a food and then not giving it regularly may result in a food allergy developing.â€‹

A note to all families:
If you have a high-risk baby, it might be beneficial to work through allergy introduction more systematically.

What babies are considered at high risk of allergic reaction?

  • A family history of food allergies
  • Atopic eczema
  • Already allergic to one or more foods
  • Parents born in Asia

For high-risk babies, the following process is recommended for introducing allergens:

  • Day 1: Swab on lip, wait 10 mins, followed by 1/8 teaspoon
  • Day 2: 1/4 teaspoon
  • Day 3: 1/2 teaspoon
  • Day 4: 3/4 teaspoon
  • Day 5: Full teaspoon



Should breastfeeding mothers restrict allergens?
There is no evidence that restricting or increasing the intake of certain foods in a breastfeeding motherâ€™s diet will have any impact on the child.

The next section will focus on identifying and how to act if you think your baby has had an allergic reaction to a certain food.

Allergic reactions usually occur quickly - within minutes (although they can take up to 2 hours). Other reactions to foods may be delayed. Allergists can often be bombarded with long lists of foods and possible reactions from parents which are little cause for concern because parents werenâ€™t educated on what they should be looking for - this section aims to minimize this and empower you as parents.

What does an allergic reaction look like?

Signs of a mild to moderate allergic reaction in babies to a food include:

  • Swelling of the lips, face & eyes
  • Hives or welts
  • Vomiting

Note: Minor redness around the mouth is most often due to irritation and is not usually due to an allergic reaction to the food. It is best to seek advice from your doctor as children can develop vomiting and skin rashes for other reasons that are not allergy-related. It is important that babies are not avoiding a food unnecessarily as that may increase their risk of developing an allergy to that food.

Signs of a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) in babies

A baby having a severe allergic reaction to a food may experience any one of the following:

  • Difficult or noisy breathing
  • Swelling of the tongue
  • Swelling in throat (e.g. drooling, difficulty swallowing)
  • Change in voice or cry and/or difficulty vocalizing
  • Wheeze or persistent cough
  • Pale and floppy or collapse

If you are not sure whether your baby is having a severe allergic reaction or not, it is better to seek urgent medical attention as anaphylaxis can be life-threatening.

What should I do if I think my baby is having an allergic reaction?

If you notice any swelling of the lips, eyes or face, hives or welts, vomiting, or any change in your babyâ€™s well-being (becoming very unsettled) soon after giving a new food, your baby could be having an allergic reaction - stop feeding your baby that food and seek medical advice.

If your baby is showing signs of a mild to moderate allergic reaction:

  • Stay with your baby and watch to see if there are any signs of anaphylaxis
  • Discuss the use of non-drowsy antihistamines for children under one year of age with your doctor. Sedating antihistamines should not be given.

If there are signs of a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis)

  • Lay your baby flat in your arms.
  • DO NOT hold them upright.
  • DO NOT allow your baby to stand or walk.
  • If breathing is difficult, allow them to sit.
  • If they are unconscious or vomiting, place them on their side.

Immediately phone ambulance â€” triple zero â€” 000 (Australia, including mobiles).

If it is your first exposure to a certain food and you are having a severe allergic reaction it is most likely you will NOT have an adrenaline injector.

In good news, itâ€™s very uncommon for a baby to have a severe reaction to an allergen on the first exposure â€” which is why we test small amounts over a period of days.

If you have an adrenaline (epinephrine) injector (e.g. EpiPenÂ® Jr or AnapenÂ® Junior 150) - give immediately.

  • Phone ambulance â€” triple zero â€” 000 (Australia, including mobiles).
  • Note the time the adrenaline injector was given.
  • Give the used adrenaline autoinjector to ambulance staff when they arrive.

Sometimes a second dose of adrenaline is needed. If you have given the adrenaline injector and your baby still has signs of anaphylaxis or your baby appears to improve and then signs of anaphylaxis begin to show again, give a second dose of adrenaline if available.

What will happen if my baby does have a reaction to a certain food or foods?

After an episode, you will be referred by a doctor to an allergist. You can see Allergists in a public or private setting. More often than not, your allergist will do a prick test (sometimes called a puncture or scratch test) to measure your baby's allergic response to the allergen and prescribe you an adrenaline (epinephrine) injector (e.g. EpiPenÂ® Jr or AnapenÂ® Junior 150) if required.

For foods or allergens that your baby hasnâ€™t tried yet, the process is still at-home testing as above.

Tracking Allergy Reactions:

Once you have dealt with the immediate symptoms and sought medical attention, itâ€™s important to keep track of any reactions - this will be really important when talking to healthcare professionals about what has happened.

Be empowered, not alarmed

While allergies are on the rise, and we need to collectively do everything in our power to minimize the risk for our children, I donâ€™t ever want this content to be alarmist. Remember, even if youâ€™re in a high-risk category for allergies, thereâ€™s still a very low chance your baby will be allergic to anything.

Be empowered with all the knowledge around allergens BUT always approach starting solids with a sense of calm and fun so we can teach our babies to love food from the very beginning.

Packet/pouch food is amazingly convenient - itâ€™s affordable, sterile, mobile. Itâ€™s absolutely OK to use packet food. They are perfect for food on the run.

In order to achieve 12 hours of overnight sleep, I recommend 25-50g of a protein source at lunch.

When it comes to packet food and pouches I always recommend you:

1. Read the label.
There's often a lot of sugar (even if they are natural sugars, they are still sugar). What looks like vegetables could be 50% apple. Remember, our babies need to learn to eat a variety of flavors, and introducing one flavor/food at a time is important. We are also yet to find a pouch that has enough protein for this lunchtime feed. If you find one, tell us!

2. Never let a baby eat straight from the pouch.
Spoon feeding utilizes mouth muscles necessary for healthy growth and development. Additionally, toddlers can learn how to use a spoon to build fine motor skills. I always recommend using a spoon when feeding these purees. I'm not alarmist here - it's ok for toddlers to 'suck' on these pouches occasionally (we've all forgotten a spoon on the run!). However, make sure before they do this, they have started spoon-feeding themselves, eating finger foods, and drinking from a cup with minimal spilling before giving them to 'suck' on a pouch.

3. Ensure texture is introduced as your baby grows.
When food texture does not progress with the development of your baby, they are not challenged to learn how to chew. Studies have found that babies who were introduced to lumpy solids after the age of nine months ate less of the food groups at seven years old than those introduced between six and nine months old. The good news is there are now lots of baby packet foods and pouches with texture!

4. Don't depend on pouches for their only source of fruit and veg.
Packets and pouches shouldn't be the sole source of your baby's fruits and veggies. We want kids to accept fruits and vegetables in a variety of formats and textures! This is why the process of offering puree (to eat easily via the spoon), mash (to build texture and play with), and some soft finger food of the same ingredient when we introduce foods is so important.

Again, as we approach the starting of solids, my philosophy is to make food fun for both parents and babies - embrace the mess.

When you're out and about, you may not want your baby covered head to toe in what they are eating - and that's absolutely fine. Use packets and pouches when you need to, but make sure your baby is getting a variety of flavors and age-appropriate textures as they develop.

Even when you're using packets, you can still give them handheld food. There are some great dissolvable vegetable sticks that can be terrific when you're still having fun but want to minimize the mess when you're out and about!

1000â€™s of children are treated in hospital for choking each year.

Food is one of the most common items babies and children choke on.

Avoiding: popcorn, whole grapes, hard lollies & marshmallows in the first couple of years will minimize risk. Avoid whole nuts until your child is 5.

Top safety tips for solids:

ðŸ¥£ Avoid giving hard chewy foods and small solid pieces of food to young children.
ðŸ¥£ Grate, mash, or chop these foods for children.
ðŸ¥£ Remove bones from young childrenâ€™s food.
ðŸ¥£ Never force a distressed child to eat.

Cutting, mashing, and grating foods are all ways you can help to reduce the risk as your baby/toddler learns to eat.

I hear regularly in my consults"I'm worried my baby is allergic to something in my breastmilk."It is extremely important to highlight the difference between allergy and intolerance.

Babies canâ€™t be allergic to their motherâ€™s milk. However, it is possible to be intolerant to something the breastfeeding mother has eaten or drunk, which then passes to the baby via breastmilk. With intolerance, the more exposure, the more symptoms. This is different from an allergy, where even the smallest exposure triggers a reaction.

Note: Intolerances are common in both bottle-fed and breastfed babies.

The more common symptoms of intolerance include:

  • Mucus (in moderate-severe cases, blood) in the stool
  • Irritability
  • Eczema
  • Difficulties with weight gain

Mucus in Poo: ðŸ’©

You can see mucus in the poo by its shineâ€”if you hold the nappy together and pull it apart, you'll see strings like power lines. Mucus in the poo is a sign of inflammation.

The most common foods babies can be intolerant to are:

  • Cowâ€™s milk
  • Soy
  • Rice
  • Egg
  • Corn
  • Gluten

What to do if you think your baby is intolerant to something?

  • My first recommendation if you're seeing a lot of mucusy poos is to consider food exclusion.
  • If your baby is bottle-fed, you may want to try a non-cowâ€™s milk-based formula.
  • If youâ€™re breastfeeding, you may want to decrease or avoid cowâ€™s milk products first.

Breastfeeding & exclusion diets:

  • It can take 2-3 days for a food group to leave your system and a few more days to see results in your babyâ€”don't expect immediate changes.
  • If limiting cowâ€™s milk doesnâ€™t help, try eliminating soy next. For most babies, this should solve the issue. If symptoms persist, follow the list above in order.
  • Breastfeeding is one of the hardest jobs out thereâ€”this shouldn't be too strict. If your baby has strong weight gain, is settled, and sleeping well, there's no reason to deprive yourself of essential food. Small amounts of mucus can be tolerated.
  • Breastfeeding diets need to stay balanced. If you're removing food groups, talk to your GP about maintaining proper nutrition, as this is crucial for milk supply.
  • Once your baby's stools have been normal for a while, you can slowly reintroduce excluded foods. If your baby remains happy and the stools stay normal, you'll know you're back on track.
  • Depending on severity, you can try reintroducing foods after about a month.

Some notes on intolerances/mucus in poo:

  • Mucus in the poo is a sign of inflammation but is not always a major concernâ€”if your baby has strong weight gain, is settled, and sleeping well, there is no need to panic.
  • If your baby is irritable, has trouble sleeping, or struggles with weight gain, it may be worth investigating further.

Remember: This advice is general. If you are concerned about intolerances, discuss them with your babyâ€™s doctor.

Between 4-6 weeks old you are probably still very much getting to know your baby and vice versa. 

Because of this I recommend following your babyâ€™s rhythm between weeks 4-6. 

The rhythm includes listening to your baby and watching them closely, keeping in mind what their rough awake time should be and looking for their tired signs, before promptly offering a nappy change if needed, swaddling, and putting them to bed. Donâ€™t stress about militant routines at this stage as every day is likely to look a bit different and this is very normal. 

You can begin starting to establish a more firm routine for your baby from about 6 weeks old and 5-6 kg. 

These neednâ€™t be rigid times and the most important thing is to continue monitoring for your babyâ€™s tired signs. When tired, begin your wind-down nap routine and pop them down within 10 minutes. This will help prevent your baby from becoming overtired (which makes them difficult to settle). 

If your baby is closer to 6 weeks, they will need an awake time closer to 1.5 hours. Then as they grow towards 12 weeks they can have a longer awake time closer to 2 hours.  

These suggested routines are flexible and all times should include 30 minutes of â€˜give or takeâ€™ at any time of the day or night.

Our program recommends that babies this age be on 3 naps per day, with the third nap being quite short - to discourage a late bedtime. I recommend a short-long-short daytime nap routine for the reasons below, however, if your family isnâ€™t able to adopt this routine then an alternative is a medium-medium-short nap routine. Often in this age group, the second nap begins to consolidate for babies who have previously catnapped during the daytime.

Natural nap windows occur between 9-10am, 12-2pm, and 6-7pm, where the bodyâ€™s circadian rhythm and sleep hormones (primarily melatonin) are primed for sleep, so offering naps at these times is ideal. Youâ€™ll notice there is no natural nap window for the late afternoon nap. This is why the late afternoon nap can often be difficult for some babies, and letting them sleep in the pram/car/carrier here is okay.

Naps occurring at the right time make the child feel rested. Levels of cortisol, a hormone that increases with stress, dramatically fall during a nap, indicating a reduction in stress in the body. Not taking a needed nap means the body remains stressed. Brief naps or naps that are out of sync with other biological rhythms are less restful and less restorative. But a short nap is better than no nap at all.

A longer lunchtime nap is more restorative and consists of deeper sleep, leading to being less overtired at tonightâ€™s bedtime. Apart from the late afternoon nap, try to encourage less motion-associated sleep from now on, as it is less restorative, so fewer naps in the swing/carrier/pram/car/etc.

Waking them at around 7am every day will keep their day on track for naps and provide consistency, which babies thrive on. Every routine here is specifically formulated to not just achieve a happy, well-settled baby - but also to â€˜set you upâ€™ for the next phase. To demonstrate the point: teaching your baby to have a longer lunchtime nap at 4 months makes it easier to transition them to 2 naps between 7-8 months, and also to 1 nap between 15-18 months.

TIP: It's so important to wake your baby from their naps if they are having longer than mentioned in the routines below. Our goal is to protect overnight sleep and also encourage the lunchtime nap to be the longest of the day, so waking them from their morning nap is the best thing to help this!

If your baby has not yet started solids, we've altered the routine to reflect this below. Keep in mind that until your baby is established on solids, they may still need a feed overnight between 11pm - 7am.

Routine is so important in a babyâ€™s world! It gives them predictability and an expectation of how their day will look, and this means nap time and bedtime is something they grow to love and look forward to. Iâ€™ve worked with hundreds of babies and helped them learn to love their sleep and see them reach out for their cots in anticipation of peaceful sleep.

Natural nap windows occur between 9-10am, 12-2pm, and 6-7pm, where the bodyâ€™s circadian rhythm and sleep hormones (primarily melatonin) are primed for sleep, so offering naps at these times is ideal. Youâ€™ll notice there is no natural nap window for the late afternoon nap. This is why the late afternoon nap can often be difficult for some babies, and letting them sleep in the pram/car/carrier here is okay.

Naps occurring at the right time make the child feel rested. Levels of cortisol, a hormone that increases with stress, dramatically fall during a nap, indicating a reduction in stress in the body. Not taking a needed nap means the body remains stressed. Brief naps or naps that are out of sync with other biological rhythms are less restful and less restorative. But a short nap is better than no nap at all.

A longer lunchtime nap is more restorative and consists of deeper sleep, leading to being less overtired at tonightâ€™s bedtime. Apart from the late afternoon nap, try to encourage less motion-associated sleep from now on, as it is less restorative, so fewer naps in the swing/carrier/pram/car/etc.

Waking them at around 7am every day will keep their day on track for naps and provide consistency, which babies thrive on. The 6-8 month age group marks a big transition in your babyâ€™s routine, dropping from 3 naps to 2. In this section, I will guide you through how to navigate the nap transition and also offer a couple of different options as to what routine might suit your family the best.

TIP: It's so important to wake your baby from their naps if they are having longer than mentioned in the routines below. Our goal is to protect overnight sleep and also encourage the lunchtime nap to be the longest of the day, so waking them from their morning nap is the best thing to help this!

This option is for babies in the 6-8 month age group who arenâ€™t quite ready to drop to 2 naps. When they are showing signs to drop to 2 naps, they might still have a 3 nap day every now and then until they completely transition.

Adopting a more 'go with the flow' approach once your baby has transitioned to 2 naps.

Once your baby is on 2 naps and isnâ€™t cat-napping, you may choose to follow the 2-3-4 rule. Awake time from waking to first nap is 2-2.5 hours, then 3 hours between morning nap and afternoon nap, and 4 hours awake from the last nap until bedtime. This is a more flexible option if parents prefer this to a strict routine.

By 8 months your baby is physiologically able to sleep through the night. At this age, if they are taking too many calories overnight, this can affect how much they take during the day, and a milk-solids imbalance can come into play. Your baby should be on 3 solid meals by now and possibly with 1-2 snacks as well as 3-4 day milk feeds.

If your baby is waking up in the morning and not seeming interested in a full milk feed or solids, then this is a clear sign that they are having too much overnight, which is affecting their intake during the day.

In our last program (Big Babies 4-8 months), we recommended dropping overnight feeds and guided you on how to do this. If your baby is still having a night feed, then it is achievable to drop this feed and teach your baby to sleep through the night.

For a full explanation, watch the video below, but as a general guide:

Breastfed: Reduce your babyâ€™s time at the breast by 2 minutes every couple of nights until the feed is dropped.

Bottle-fed: Reduce the volume of your babyâ€™s bottle by 30ml every couple of nights until you are down to 60ml, then drop the feed.

If your baby is having 2 feeds overnight, then I recommend dropping the second feed first (usually the one between 2-5 am) and keeping the earlier feed. Then, once your baby has successfully dropped the second feed, go ahead and drop the remaining feed.

Lesson Name: Tips for Stretching Your Babyâ€™s Wake Windows
Lesson Content:
Stretching your baby's wake windows can be difficult, and sometimes no matter what you try, they just won't be able to keep their little eyes open. The best way to stretch their wake window is to do it gradually, by adding just 10-15 minutes to each awake period, every few days.

For babies on 3 naps, the last awake period of the day may not be able to be stretched, and this can be normal. Babies will be at their most tired towards the end of the day, just like adults, and the worst thing to do here is stretch them too much and create overtiredness before bedtime. Our awake times in this program are just a guide - remember that every baby is different, and your baby might cope well with slightly shorter or longer awake times than what is recommended.

Tips to help extend your baby's awake times:

Tip 1: Face-to-face time with your baby with a song or nursery rhyme.

Tip 2: Playtime in a different room of the house - if your baby has been playing in one room of the house, then taking them to a different room for the last little bit of their awake time can distract them enough with a change of scenery.

Tip 3: Taking them outside in the fresh air to look at the trees and environment around them - a burst of sunshine before a nap also helps with melatonin production!

Tip 4: A brief walk in the pram - be careful your baby doesn't fall asleep here if you're wanting them to stay awake and go to sleep in their cot/bassinet. The morning nap and 3rd nap of the day are great ones to have while out and about.

Tip 5: Offering a small top-up feed before their nap.

Please see our lessons on early morning waking in Chapter 1.3 - Routines.

Below is a contingency plan of what to do if your baby wakes early.

Under 5 months old
Power nap: If your baby has woken early (i.e., pre 6.15 am) and will not resettle, then a power nap can be used until 5 months old. A power nap is a small 15-minute nap ONLY to help get your baby through to their next nap time and keep their day on track. Allowing them to only have 15 minutes may seem cruel, but we want to avoid them falling into a very deep sleep, as this will decrease their drive to sleep, making their next nap harder to achieve.

So your morning might look something like this:
6 am - Wake up, unable to be resettled
7.15 am - Power nap
7.30 am - Wake baby up
9 am - Nap 1 back on track.

A power nap is only a temporary solution and should only be used for a few days in a row, as we donâ€™t want it to become a new habit.

Over 5 months old:
If your baby wakes early, try your best to stretch them out until as close to their normal nap time as possible. A little walk around the garden or playtime in a different room might help pass the time if they are more fussy and tired than usual because of the early wake-up.

Double check why your baby might be waking - and think of hunger as the last option.

Could they be overtired or under-tired from the previous day's sleep?

  • Double check the age bracket your baby is in and if their day sleep matches what's in their age-appropriate routine. It can be tempting to let them take extra long naps and have some bonus time to yourself - but most likely, this will bite you in the bottom overnight.

Are they too cold?

  • In my experience, this is the most common reason a baby wakes around 4am (the coldest part of the night). Double check what TOG they are wearing and the temperature of the room. If it's not 18-21Â°C, think about a heater option.

Are they too hot?

  • This is less common but still something to think about.

Is the morning light coming in and waking them up?

  • This is a HUGE one. If you havenâ€™t invested in blackout blinds and your baby is waking as the sun comes up, this is probably the reason.

Could it be wind?

  • See my content on colic and wind signs to dive further into this. Most of the time, due to it being the middle of the night, we donâ€™t wind as effectively or for as long for evening or night feeds - this can lead to wind and may make them very uncomfortable in the early hours.

Is it a dirty nappy?

  • It seems obvious, but if thereâ€™s a poo, you need to change it. Iâ€™m yet to meet a baby that will sleep comfortably with a soiled nappy. Most babies will handle a slightly wet nappy, but if itâ€™s super full (if they are cold and have been having lots of overnight feeds, it probably is), you will need to change this too. Keep the lights low or off and just use the torch on your phone - calm and dark for overnight changes is the key.

Do they have eczema that could be bothering them?

  • Like colic, if they are uncomfortable, it will be impossible to get them to sleep. Work with your doctor to get on top of any eczema.

And lastly, are they hungry?

  • The reason why we look at hunger last is that if a baby is fed as soon as they wake before 7am, they take in calories, which means they won't be as hungry or have as full of a feed in the morning. The cycle of too many calories overnight and not enough during the day continues - this is often referred to as reverse cycling. Revisit the video on dropping night feeds for more on this.

For all early morning waking, keep the lights preferably off or as low as possible and limit all interaction: this isn't the time to sing songs and chat to them, as we want to try and keep them as sleepy as possible - the less stimulation, the better.

Early Morning Waking FAQs

Q. What should I do if my baby wakes before 5am?
A. Go through the above checklist and rule out common reasons for waking. Try to resettle your baby using your chosen settling technique (chapter 1.8 - settling and calming babies). If you feel your baby is hungry, then feed as needed, as a hungry baby won't resettle. Once your baby is over 5-6kg and over 6 weeks old, then you can try to reduce this feed gradually. Please refer back to the Dropping Night Feeds video in this lesson.

Q. What should I do if my baby wakes between 5-6am?
A. Go through the above checklist and rule out common reasons for waking. Try to resettle your baby using your chosen settling technique. If your baby needs a feed, then at this hour of the day, I recommend offering a half feed (either a smaller bottle or fewer minutes at the breast) and then putting them back to bed, treating it like a night wake-up. Continue to wake them around 7/7:30am (or the usual time you wake them) to start their day. As feeds help set their circadian rhythm, I suggest continuing to decrease the amount offered at this time until they're sleeping through until closer to 7am.

Most babies are ready to drop to 2 naps between 7-8 months old, some as early as 6 months.

Signs they are ready to drop the late afternoon cat-nap include:

  • Suddenly waking frequently overnight, particularly between the hours of 1-3am
  • Taking longer to fall asleep at bedtime
  • Fighting the afternoon catnap consistently for more than 1 week

When you drop the 3rd nap, bedtime will need to be moved earlier to help them adjust. This transition can take a couple of weeks. Move bedtime to 6/6.15pm and remember that putting them down earlier will help keep on top of overtiredness, which in turn will reduce the likelihood of overnight waking and early morning waking. They may still need a cat-nap every 2nd or 3rd day for a little while or on days where they havenâ€™t had a long lunchtime nap.

If your baby is in childcare or looked after by a relative, then itâ€™s really important to have everyone on board with their routine.

This consistency is in your baby's best interest and will help their night sleep if every day is roughly the same. I encourage you to print off or write your childâ€™s routine down for their childcare educators or caregivers and explain why itâ€™s important to you that they respect your babyâ€™s routine. Of course, there will be times when your babyâ€™s routine is thrown off, for example with travel or sickness, but having the skills and knowledge to get them back into an age-appropriate routine is the most important thing.

What is a roll-over feed?

A roll-over feed is suitable for late evening feeds (they work really well for some, not all babies). They involve gently waking your baby but keeping stimulation to a minimum, like â€˜rollingâ€™ one sleep into the next. Lights are kept dim, and there are minimal interactions. While a roll-over feed is likely to be smaller than a full daytime feed, it is far more filling than a dream feed.

What is a dream feed?

A dream feed is a feed where your baby stays asleep or is aroused to a lighter stage of sleep.

These are suitable for babies over 6 weeks old. You may choose to keep the stimulation to a minimum or try to maintain sleep throughout.

Roll-over vs. dream feed?
Both are reasonable options - your baby will tell you which they prefer.

How do I offer a dream feed?

This feed can be offered by both breast and bottle, and if youâ€™re wanting to introduce a bottle into your babyâ€™s routine, this is the perfect time to add it (I recommend this after 4-6 weeks when breastmilk supply has been established).

Step 1: Gently pick up your sleeping baby out of the bassinet or crib.
Step 2: Keep your baby swaddled or in their sleeping bag.
Step 3: Position yourself comfortably as you would for any regular feed.
Step 4: Gently tease your babyâ€™s mouth with the nipple or bottle teat until they open enough to latch.

  • If itâ€™s difficult, try stroking their cheek or lips to stimulate their rooting reflex and encourage them to take the nipple.

Step 5: Give your baby a bottle or breastfeed.

  • Some babies will only take one side of the breast or a smaller amount than they usually would in a bottle compared to a regular feedâ€”this is normal.

Step 6: Make sure your baby is well-winded.

  • Even though itâ€™s a quick feed, itâ€™s important not to miss this. This will help stop them from waking in the middle of the night from trapped wind and help them sleep longer. You can absolutely burp them while they are asleep/half asleep.

Step 7: After a quick cuddle, put your drowsy baby back to sleep in their crib or bassinet.

Dream feeds donâ€™t work for every babyâ€”some will wake too much and be difficult to resettle, while others just refuse to feed while still asleep. I recommend continuing to try a dream feed for at least 1 week, as it can take this long for it to be successful. Dads can offer the dream feed with a bottle, while mum goes to bed earlier for the night.

Dream feeds are often much smaller and less satisfying than feeding when awake and may not give them the calories they need to sleep through until 7 am reliably. However, if your baby is sleeping through till morning with a dream feed, there is nothing you need to change!

Dream feeds should not be offered past 7 months old. Disturbing their night sleep at this age can be counterproductive and actually increase night waking, so after 7 months, let your baby wake on their own for a feed overnight if needed.

Tips for a successful roll-over or dream feed

Tip 1: Keep the lights dim and stimulation to a minimumâ€”try to use a hallway light or a dim, small night light to help stop your baby from waking fully.
Tip 2: Only change their nappy if it is heavy or soiled. If necessary, change the nappy before the feed and only unswaddle their bottom half to try and keep them as drowsy and settled as possible.
Tip 3: If offering a bottle, have it all ready to go so you don't have to leave the room to prepare it.
Tip 4: Leave the white noise playing to help keep your baby calm and quiet.

FAQs on the Late Night Feed

Q: My baby is going down at 7 pm and sleeps to 3-4 am. I'm hesitant to wake them for the 10 pm/11 pm roll-over/dream feed. Do I still need to wake them?
A: YES, absolutely. The reason I recommend this late evening feed is that we are aiming to consolidate the nice long stretch overnight and get your baby sleeping as close to 7 am as possible. The 3-4 am feed is what we are aiming to drop first, followed by the 10/11 pm evening feed (once solids are established).

Q: How long should a dream feed be?
A: Let your baby feed for as long as they want to. It might be 5 to 15 minutes at the breast or 60-120ml in a bottle. As mentioned above, sometimes this feed isn't a full feeding because your baby is still drowsy or asleep, and this is fine.

Q: Is breast or bottle feeding best here?
A: Babies can be breastfed or bottle-fed with expressed milk or formula at this feed. It's a great feed to offer a bottle at as it means mum can go to bed earlier, and dad or the non-breastfeeding parent can still offer the feedâ€”again, taking into consideration that I don't recommend this until breastmilk supply has been established if you're breastfeeding.

Q: How do I know if the dream feed is working for my baby?
A: Dream feeds are supposed to help babies sleep for a longer stretch and be easier to put back down to bed. If this isn't happening and night wakings are continuing frequently despite trying for a week, then it might be best to let your baby wake on their own for a feed or wake them and feed at 10/11 pm instead.

Dream feeds are fantastic, but in my experience, they don't work for all babies, and this is okay.

Lesson Name: The Importance of Play Time in Their Bedroom
Lesson Content:
A huge part of helping your baby sleep well is ensuring they feel safe, secure, and comfortable in their sleep space. For this reason, I always suggest including some playtime in their bedroom a couple of times a day to help them see their bedroom as a happy and fun place to be, and not one of fear and anxiety and a place they only go to sleep. Just 10-15 minutes a couple of times a day is all that is needed. Read some books, sing songs, take some of their favourite toys in there and make it fun. If you are still room sharing then I recommend the playtime be split between their current sleep space and also their own bedroom that they will eventually transition into.

If your baby is already familiar and comfortable with their bedroom it will make the transition a whole lot easier!

The recommended routines will give you a guide as to how your day will look; however, we appreciate that you will still need to get out of the house, sometimes during suggested nap times. While your baby is still little, it is a great time to get out and about, as generally, the younger they are, the better babies will sleep while on the go since movement can be a helpful settling tool.

It's important to note that after around 6 months of age, sleep on the go (in the pram, carrier, or car seat) is usually less restorative. Your baby will be more likely to wake after one sleep cycle and may be difficult to get back to sleep. At this age, you donâ€™t have to offer all naps in a dark room in your babyâ€™s bassinet or cot; however, we do suggest offering at least one nap a day at home in an ideal sleep environment (think white noise, as dark as possible, and a comfortable temperature).

Sometimes routines are disrupted and naps have to be â€˜on the runâ€™.

A good balance is the 80/20 ruleâ€”most sleep (80%) occurs in a normal sleep environment (their nursery, daycare, grandparentâ€™s house, etc.), but on-the-go life (20%) is allowed to happen too! If sleep is disturbed or missed, remember that every morning is a chance to reset and start freshâ€”never be disheartened.

FOCUS: From around 12 weeks old, the nap we want to focus on being the longest and most restorative is the lunchtime nap. This is because it helps keep overtiredness at bay and sets you up for a better night. It is also the nap your baby will continue having until they are around 3 years old, so teaching them early to have a longer nap here helps in the long term. As much as possible, offer the lunchtime nap at home in their cot and focus on resettling your baby if they wake early.

To help your baby sleep while out and about during the day, try to recreate their sleep environment as much as possible:

  • Darken the pram with a breathable blackout cover. Don't use a blanket, as this doesn't usually provide enough darkness and the temperature in the pram can become dangerously high.
  • Use the same white noise or nature sounds that you use at home. There are many portable white noise machines available that run on batteries.
  • If your baby is still swaddled and you want to encourage them to nap in the pram, use the same swaddle you do at home.
  • If you have to head out during your baby's lunchtime nap, then occasionally offering a longer morning nap and two shorter naps later in the day is okayâ€”but try not to make this a regular pattern. You might also notice your baby is more tired at bedtime, so donâ€™t stretch them outâ€”bring bedtime earlier.

If you are going out for dinner occasionally, we recommend the following changes:

  • If you are heading out to a restaurant, then giving your baby a slightly longer third nap (or a fourth nap if they haven't slept well during the day) will allow you to push bedtime out a bit. If your baby falls asleep in the car on the way home, attempt to transfer them to their cot. However, if they wake up, this is okay. Offer a small top-up feed and put them to bed.
  • If you are visiting family or friends, try to recreate their usual sleep environment as much as possible. Make sure the room is as dark as possible, use your white noise/nature sounds, use the same swaddle or fitted cot sheet so it smells like home, and bring any comforters or dummies your baby uses at sleep time.

Red Nose Australia and the American Academy of Paediatrics (AAP) don't promote sleeping in car seats for long periods of time due to the increased risk of SIDS. Babies are top heavy (their head is disproportionately heavier than the rest of them) and when they sit in an upright inclined position like they do in a car seat or capsule it may cause your baby's neck to flex forward or chin down which may block their airway. Never leave a baby asleep unsupervised in a car seat or capsule.

Babies this young can become overtired quickly, and their tired signs can be easy to misinterpret.

1. Have Realistic Expectations

  • Your baby is still very young, and not every nap will be perfect.
  • Try offering at least one nap in the bassinet or cot during the day.
  • Focus on lengthening one nap at a time.
  • Every day will be differentâ€”enjoy your baby and donâ€™t stress over small things.

2. Recalibrate with Assisted Naps (If Needed)

  • If your baby's sleep has become chaotic, use 3 days of assisted naps (pram, car seat, carrier, or being held).
  • This helps reset their sleep and avoid built-up overtiredness.
  • After 3 days, start removing this sleep association and introduce a consistent age-appropriate routine.

3. Avoid Overstimulation

  • Before naps, create a calm environment and watch for tired signs.
  • Avoid keeping them awake in a busy, noisy room or passing them around too much.

4. Resettle for a Short Time Only

  • Try to resettle your baby for a maximum of 30 minutes.
  • If they wonâ€™t resettle, itâ€™s okay to continue the nap in a pram, carrier, or being held.

5. Use a Power Nap (If Age-Appropriate)

  • If your baby is 12 weeks or older and wakes early from a nap, use a 15-minute power nap.
  • Wake them before they enter deep sleep to avoid disrupting the next nap.
  • Example: If your baby wakes too early at 5:45 AM, offer a 7:15â€“7:30 AM power nap, then continue their routine.

6. Remember That Both Parents and Babies Get Tired

  • Overtired babies = overtired parents.
  • Be kind to yourself and ask for help when needed.

Does your baby go to bed in the evening and then wake after 30-45 mins?

Itâ€™s like theyâ€™re treating bedtime as a nap and seem completely awake after one sleep cycle â€“ these are called false starts.
False starts happen for a few different reasons and can be incredibly frustrating for parents when you think youâ€™ve finally got your baby down for the night.

THE MAIN CAUSES OF FALSE STARTS ARE:

Over-tiredness

  • When your baby is overtired, they go to bed at night with a high level of circulating cortisol, our stress hormone.
  • This makes it harder for them to connect sleep cycles, and they will often wake before going into a deep sleep, crying and inconsolable.

Under-tiredness

  • This happens when your baby has had too much sleep during the day or napped too close to bedtime and doesnâ€™t have enough sleep pressure (or sleep debt) built up.
  • Try extending their awake time and ensure youâ€™re following an age-appropriate routine.

Unable to link sleep cycles yet

  • At this young age, it's very normal for your baby to not link their sleep cycles yet, and they may need assistance from you to help them back to sleep.
  • Settling techniques like shush-pat, rocking, holding, or replacing a dummy can help.
  • Some babies wonâ€™t learn to link sleep cycles until closer to 4-5 months.
  • Focus on creating an ideal sleep environment, eliminating hurdles, and sticking to an appropriate wake window/routine.

Inappropriate daytime routine

  • Babies thrive on routine, and if they are in a routine that includes too much or too little day sleep, theyâ€™re more likely to experience false starts at bedtime.
  • Review your babyâ€™s nap times and adjust them if they could be contributing to overnight sleep issues.

Sleep environment

  • This is particularly important during months and locations with daylight savings time.
  • Make sure your babyâ€™s bedroom is as dark as possible, as too much light coming in can encourage them to wake after one sleep cycle before the sun fully sets.

Lesson Name: Power Naps for Babies Under 5 Months
Lesson Content:
Power naps are really helpful to help keep the day on track while still establishing a routine and teaching your baby to link their sleep cycles. They are only useful for babies under 5 months though. This is because if they're offered to babies over 5 months old, it's more likely they'll completely refuse the next nap, which can end in an overtired, cranky baby and the whole day being out of sync.

Power naps can be used:

  • if your baby has woken early in the morning and didn't resettle, i.e., before 6.15/6.30am
  • if your baby has woken early from a nap and didn't resettle, i.e., woke after 30 mins into the morning nap and is unlikely to make it until the next suggested nap time

The most important thing about a power nap is that you MUST wake your baby after 15 mins. This is crucial; otherwise, they'll fall into a deep sleep at the 20-minute mark and be more likely to completely refuse the next nap. This seems cruel waking them, but it's the best thing to do to help them establish a routine and learn to link their sleep cycles.

Power naps can be assisted naps or contact naps - they don't have to be in the cot or bassinet. Because they're so brief, it's fine to help them sleep however possible. Below are a couple of examples of how you would use a power nap.

Example 1:
9am - morning nap
9.30am - woke up, resettled for 30 mins but unable to go back to sleep
10am - out of cot with a happy wake-up
11.15am - 11.30am - power nap
12.30pm - nap 1 back on track. We don't give the full awake window here because a 15 min power nap isn't restorative like a 1-2 hour nap is.

Example 2:
6am - wake up and unable to be resettled.
7.45am - 8am - power nap
9.15am - nap 1

Lesson Name: How to Navigate an Unplanned Nap
Lesson Content:
If your baby is over 6 weeks old and you're trying to establish a routine, it can be stressful if they fall asleep while you're out and about, and many parents worry about throwing the routine off for the day.

At this young age, it's important to remember that every day might still be a bit different, and naps that occur off routine aren't the end of the world.

If your baby falls asleep as youâ€™re walking home in the pram or in the car (these are the most likely scenarios), try and keep them awake and stimulated as much as possible.

  • If thereâ€™s a passenger in the car, tickle their chin
  • Wind the windows down and let in some fresh air
  • If they are in the pram, have them face you so you can keep them engaged
  • You may look deranged in the front seat or walking alongâ€¦ but if you know, you knowâ€¦ sometimes all you need is an extra 5 minutes to get home, and you know theyâ€™ll sleep the full 2 hoursâ€¦ PLEASE STAY AWAKE LITTLE ONE!!

If they do nod off, itâ€™s not the end of the world - there are 2 main options:

OPTION 1:
If they do fall asleep, you could treat this as a power nap and wake them after 10-15 minutes. This works better for babies between 3-5 months old. Be flexible with their routine if this happens - restart their awake time, but depending on age, bear in mind they probably wonâ€™t make the full awake window before getting tired again.

OPTION 2:
If you have the time, allow them to complete their full sleep and take the long walk or drive home. Pick up a coffee (decaf if youâ€™re planning to breastfeed in the next hour or so), turn on a podcast, and settle in.

Q: What is the cut-off wake-up time for a power nap (babies under 5 months old)?

ANS: If your baby wakes before 6.15am, then they may need a power nap. Anything after that, and you can try to stretch them closer to their normal nap time. Remember, power naps should only be offered under 5 months old.

Q: Is it ok to wake my baby from their naps?
ANS: Yes, and you should! We want to make sure your baby is having the ideal amount of day sleep for their age, and this will lead to more consolidated sleep overnight. Waking them from their first nap is very important as they see that sleep as a continuation of night sleep, so if they have too long here, it can lead to increased night wake-ups and early morning rising.

Q: Iâ€™ve noticed my baby is super crabby and seems grumpy since starting the new routine. Is this normal?
ANS: Yes, it can be normal as your baby adjusts to their new routine. There can also be some more sleep debt initially as we teach your baby to resettle and consolidate their sleep overnight. This should be short-lived, and as sleep increases, your baby will be happier and less tired.

Q: Why is the lunchtime nap the longest of the day?
ANS: We want the lunchtime nap to be the longest of the day as it is the most restorative and deepest sleep. It falls within a natural nap window, which makes it easier for your baby to sleep at this time. Having a long nap here also leads to a reduction in the stress hormone cortisol and will lead to less overtiredness at bedtime, which sets your baby up for a better nightâ€™s sleep.

Q: What is a dream feed?
ANS: A dream feed is a feed where your baby stays asleep or is aroused to a lighter stage of sleep. Itâ€™s often referred to as a roll-over feed. You may choose to keep the stimulation to a minimum or try to maintain sleep throughoutâ€”both are reasonable optionsâ€”your baby will tell you which they prefer.

To do a dream feed, gently pick your baby up and tease their mouth with the nipple or bottle teat until they open their mouth. Offer the feed as usual, all while keeping your baby swaddled or in their sleeping bag, and avoid changing their nappy as this will wake them fully. If offering a bottle here, try and keep the volume to under 150ml as too much at the dream feed can cause excessive wind or a tummy upset. When finished, bring your baby to a vertical position and begin the winding sequence. Babies who dream feed still need winding, but the amount of burps brought up may be less as they often do not feed as vigorously and take in as much air. Once they have been winded, simply lie your baby back down in their cot.

Dream feeds donâ€™t work for every babyâ€”some will wake too much and be difficult to resettle, and others just refuse to feed while still asleep. I recommend continuing to try a dream feed for at least 1 week as it can take this long for it to be successful. Dads can offer the dream feed with a bottle while mum goes to bed earlier for the night.

If you donâ€™t offer a dream feed, then just waiting for the baby to wake on their own for a feed is perfectly ok too.

Dream feeds should not be offered past 6-7 months old. Disturbing their night sleep at this age can be counterproductive and actually increase night waking, so after 6-7 months, let your baby wake on their own for a feed overnight if needed.

Q: Iâ€™m doing a dream feed, but my baby has started waking before the dream feed. What do I do about this?
ANS: This is most likely from habitual hunger or overtiredness. Ensure your baby is having an early enough bedtime as per the routine in our program. Habitual hunger can develop when your baby is used to having a feed at a certain time. If your baby wakes and it hasnâ€™t been 4 hours since their last feed, then resettle them using your settling technique. If they are still awake when it has been 4 hours, then go ahead and feed them.

Q: How do I drop the dream feed?
ANS: When your baby reaches 6-7 months, it's time to drop the dream feed. This can be done in 2 ways.

  1. If your baby isn't having quite enough protein at lunchtime yet or still getting used to solids, then I suggest gradually weaning the dream feed. To do this, drop their feed volume by 20-30ml every 2-3 nights until they are having 30ml, then drop it and let them sleep through. If breastfeeding, then reduce the time offered at the breast by 1-2 mins every couple of nights.

  2. If your baby is taking well to solids and having 25-50g of a protein source at lunchtime, then it's ok to attempt to drop the dream feed in one night. If they wake later in the night wanting a feed, then you might need to go back to offering the dream feed again and gradually wean it.

Q: We have an appointment right in the middle of my babyâ€™s nap time. What should I do about this?
ANS: Sometimes things like this are inevitable, so just roll with it for the day and try to keep your babyâ€™s routine on track as much as possible. Having one day that is a bit different occasionally wonâ€™t hurt your babyâ€™s routine long-term. Giving them a little longer on these days at their other naps is ok to ensure their total day sleep is on track.

Q: What is a happy wake-up, and why do I have to wake my baby up with one of these?
ANS: A happy wake-up is where you enter your babyâ€™s room and gently wake them but then open the curtains or turn on a light and make a big over-the-top song and dance about what a good sleep they had. This will teach your baby the difference between â€œI need to go back to sleepâ€ or â€œitâ€™s time to get up now.â€ If you are in the room resettling your baby and itâ€™s their get-up time, then leave the room briefly and re-enter to do a happy wake-up. Even though they didnâ€™t go back to sleep, give them lots of praise for staying in their cot.

Q: Can we start our day at 6am or 8am if the recommended 7am doesn't work for our family?
ANS: Absolutely! It's always ok to do what's best for your family. However, some babies do find it harder to get into a 6-6 or 8-8 routine, and this is because of the natural nap windows we have discussed in section 1.3. As there are times during the day when babies are primed for sleep due to temperature and hormone regulation, adjusting their routines permanently can suit some babies perfectly well, but it just may not work for others. Try your best and see how your baby responds, and remember to be consistent and persistent while you attempt the change.

A circadian rhythm is the bodyâ€™s natural sleep-wake cycle, lasting 24 hours. The main hormone involved in this process is melatonin. Light drives our melatonin levels down, and darkness allows it to rise. This rise in melatonin is what makes us sleepy and helps us drift off to sleep each night. As light increases in the morning, cortisol begins to circulate, which is like our bodyâ€™s natural coffee hit, driving wakefulness.

Babies mostly rely on their motherâ€™s circadian rhythm but need to develop their own soon after birth. It is well established by 3 months of age, and there are many things you can do to help this process.

Lesson Name: Sleep Associations (Feeding, Rocking and Patting to Sleep)
Lesson Content:
There is a very important, very fundamental rule about humans: the way we fall asleep is the way we expect to wake up. It may sound silly, but if you fell asleep in your bed tonight and woke in the middle of the night in the same place, you roll over, go back to sleep - and donâ€™t remember. But if you woke in another room - you would startle awake and look to find out how/why things have changed. Babies are the same. If they fall asleep being rocked in their motherâ€™s arms, then at the end of a sleep cycle, they will wonder where that parent is - and be unable to stitch together multiple cycles.

Whenever possible, put your baby down sleepy, but awake.

Many parents will report their baby only sleeping one cycle at a time - well, this is usually the reason. Itâ€™s what drives the inability to self-soothe and stitch together cycles.

Lesson Name: Introducing Sleepy Words and a Happy Wake Up
Lesson Content:
As part of any routine, even from this early age, both parents should find a phrase or some sleepy words that you can say to your baby as you put them down for sleep. It doesnâ€™t have to be lengthy, but just a few words they will quickly begin to recognise as a sleep cue. Something like â€œnight night, itâ€™s sleep time now, love youâ€, or â€œitâ€™s sleepy time now, sweet dreamsâ€. Say your sleepy words right as you pop your baby in their cot for a sleep and repeat them once or twice before leaving them to fall asleep. If you need to resettle your baby, then repeat your sleepy words during the resettling process.

Introducing a happy wake-up will also help your baby learn to distinguish when it is time to go back to sleep and when it is time to wake up. A happy wake-up is where you quietly enter the room and wake the baby up, but then make a big fuss with lots of over-the-top praise about what a good sleep they had!

Your baby will learn that quiet, sleepy words mean it's time to go back to sleep, whilst a happy wake-up means it's time to get up and play.

This technique is suitable for 3-12 month olds, and can be used alone or in combination with other settling techniques such as Shush-Pat. At a younger age (i.e., under 5-6 months), patting with C2C can be effective. Over 6 months, try to reduce or stop all patting to sleep.

It is a gentler method that appeals to parents as you are able to physically console your baby using both touch and voice, so thereâ€™s no â€˜cry it outâ€™ process. There will be tears, but C2C is about instilling trust and reassurance; this takes time to develop.

Just like other settling techniques, it requires patience, hard work, and consistency.

How to do it:

Step 1: When putting your baby down to sleep, stay with them in their room. Sit next to the cot on a chair or on a cushion on the floor (avoid standing next to them as you should be at their level).

Step 2: If your baby starts crying, then use your voice and some touch to reassure them that youâ€™re there and itâ€™s sleep time.

Step 3: If the baby doesnâ€™t stop crying for a full minute (or count to 100), then pick your baby up and calm them. Try to make it a minimally-stimulating cuddle, though; minimize rocking, jiggling, or swaying.

Step 4: The second they stop crying, put them back down in the cot. You also have the option to continue using some shushing to keep them calm (and patting if younger than 6 months).

Step 5: If the cry turns into a grizzle, keep them in the cot and continue using your voice and some intermittent touch (patting if younger than 6 months).

Step 6: If they are still crying and fighting you while being held, put your baby back down and use your sleep words every few minutes such as â€œItâ€™s sleep time nowâ€ or â€œnight night time.â€ You can also use some intermittent shushing. The fighting, arching in your arms, and burrowing their head is part of them trying to go to sleep. Donâ€™t fight a crying child; put them down if they are doing this.

If you put your baby down and they cry the second they touch the mattress, wait another full minute (or count to 100), then pick them back up and repeat the process, but still ensure youâ€™re following the times.

Over the coming days, you must start to increase the length of time between pick-ups for it to be effective. For example, on the first day, we waited a full minute; on day 2, we should wait 2 minutes; on day 3 - 3 minutes, etc. Combine this with reducing the amount of touch used between cuddles.

If your baby continues to protest and not calm down with any pick-ups, then this is a sign that this technique isnâ€™t suited to your baby and you may need to consider changing it.

Settling a baby is when you initially pop them down to sleep, whereas resettling a baby is when you pop them back to sleep after waking early from a nap or waking during the night. No matter whether you are settling or resettling, it's important to use the same technique as consistency is key. The more consistent you are, the less confused your baby will be and the quicker they'll learn to self-soothe.

For example, if you have decided to use our Spaced Soothing method, then use this technique at every settle and resettle and stick with it for at least 4 days before switching techniques. Changing techniques too frequently will just confuse your baby.

At the morning nap, if they have slept less than 30 mins, I recommend resettling them for a further 30 mins. This is because a lot of the time, babies won't resettle in under 30 mins, and here we are teaching them that it's not quite time to get up yet and it's still sleep time. If they wake after one sleep cycle (40-45 mins), then I recommend resettling for a further 15 mins (or until the full hour is up). They are unlikely to go back to sleep here, but again, it's about teaching them that it's still sleep time. Once they've had the full hour in the cot, if they are awake with no signs of going back to sleep, then leave the room briefly and come back in with a happy wake-up. This will help teach them the difference between when it's time to go back to sleep and when it's time to get up and play.

At the lunchtime nap:

  • If your baby has slept for less than 40 mins, resettle for 1 hour, then get the baby up for a quick cuddle and top-up feed, then back to bed for some more sleep.
  • If your baby sleeps well but for less than 1.5 hours, resettle for a further 30-40 mins, then do a 'happy wake-up' at your baby's wake-up time.
  • If your baby sleeps well and longer than 1.5 hours, get them up with a 'happy wake-up' and lots of praise for the great sleep they had.

Overnight, if your baby wakes and you have offered a burp, checked their nappy, and checked they aren't too hot or cold, go ahead and use your chosen technique to resettle them until:
a) They are due for a feed if still on 1 feed overnight or
b) They fall back asleep if not having any feeds overnight.

There is no time limit to resettling overnight. It may sound daunting, but they will fall back to sleep, and this is the quickest way to teach them that it's still sleep time.

Regardless of which settling technique is chosen, there is bound to be some crying as the baby adjusts. Itâ€™s important to remember that this is not because your baby feels abandoned or unloved, but rather because your baby is tired or perhaps frustrated that expected reactions are not taking place. The crying should be interpreted as a protest, as opposed to pain or suffering. Babies will often protest at the changes we are making to help them learn to sleep more soundly.

I would never expect you to leave your baby or child to â€˜cry it outâ€™ and, in fact, I would never recommend others do something that I couldnâ€™t do with my own children. This program is about tuning in to your parental instinct, listening to your baby, and choosing a technique that you can be consistent with. I want to show you what your baby is capable of (itâ€™s often far more than we think!) and the best methods to achieve this.

With the settling techniques recommended, make sure you choose one that is achievable for your family! Every parent and family is different, but both caregivers should be on the same page to give your baby the same, consistent message.

Controlled crying has never been researched in children under 6 months of age. It should not be used under this age, and even beyond 6 months, it remains controversial. Capped comforting is okay in smaller babies, involving a more hands-on approach. Spaced soothing is a far more gentle approach than controlled crying and is easier on babies AND parents!

Why does my baby cry when I put them to bed?

It takes all babies a different amount of time to stop crying at bedtime. Some seem to never do it, while others take a couple of weeks to adjust. I recommend lots of playtime in their room during the day so they see it as a positive, happy place to be. If they start crying when you take them into the bedroom to put a sleeping bag on, then I suggest doing this in a different room for a few days.

Itâ€™s very normal for babies to seem more tired and distressed during sleep training, which is why I suggest lots of extra cuddles and happy play together during awake time. Some ideas include having a bath or shower together for some skin-to-skin contact and bringing them into your bed in the morning for cuddles when you all wake up.

During the sleep training process, you may notice that your baby's night sleep improves first, while naps take a little while longer to consolidate. Not all babies will experience this, but it is something to be aware of and keep in the back of your mind while implementing a new routine and/or using a new settling technique.

The cycle chart below will give you the reassurance that sleep training is a lot like 2 steps forward, 1 step back, but staying consistent and persisting with it is so important and will help you see results in no time.

Being on the same page as parents is really important when it comes to not just sleep training but how you plan to raise your kids as a couple. 

Giving your baby a consistent message from both caregivers will help them learn what is expected and how to react. 

Tips for couple alignment: 

  • If you're completing a program (like the Dr Golly Sleep Program) or even just researching different ideas make sure both caregivers complete the course or read the article 
  • If it's possible to complete research or courses together, even better!  This way you can discuss topics while they are fresh - both parents should be empowered with all the information
  • Talk openly and often about how you want to parent, the values you want to instill in your kids
  • Talk openly and often about what you don't want to do as parents, behaviors you have witnessed that you don't want to replicate  
  • Align on your strategies so your baby always gets a consistent message, for sleep training in particular this is incredibly important  e.g. remain consistent on sleepy words, settling techniques and the desired routine when you start to implement them 
  • Don't play the "Disneyland parent" - offering treats and undermining the rules you've set together 
  • Once a week have a "planning night" it's not as romantic as date night but maybe more beneficial for your relationship.  Meal plan for the week, work our what activities, workload you both have on, align on who is doing what

Parenting is the most intricate team sport there is - by aligning on your strategy, respecting each others views, engaging in the research or content, always being open to discussion and new ideas and planning together you'll find both your parenting ability and relationship will be stronger.

Q: If my baby is happy and chatting in their cot do I still go in and settle them?

ANS: No, only intervene if your baby is upset. At the end of the day we canâ€™t force them to sleep, so giving them some time to try and fall asleep and work it out themselves is the best thing to do. Remember that cot time is still rest time.

Q: What is the difference between settling vs resettling?
