ANS: Yes, it's ok to work on one thing at a time! Just do what you can, and often by working on day naps first, for example, overnight sleep improves dramatically as your baby isn't as overtired, and vice versa.

Q: How long do I try to settle my baby for at their naps before offering an assisted nap?
ANS: At 4-8 months old try to settle your baby for 1 hour before offering an assisted nap (i.e. pram, car seat, carrier, held). This sounds like a very long time but remember that the first couple of days are the hardest. Try to stay as consistent as possible and persist with your chosen technique for 4-5 days. However, if you are seeing excessive crying then see Chapter 1.5 - Choosing a settling technique.

Q: My baby has learned to roll from back to tummy and cries out during their sleep when they wake up on their tummy. What can I do about this?
ANS: This is a very common issue, and the best thing you can do is to help reassure your baby that it's ok for them to sleep on their tummies, as long as they get themselves into that position. Never put a baby down to sleep on their tummy, however, if they've learned to roll and they are unswaddled, then if they wake and are upset, reassure them and attempt to resettle them while still on their tummies. If they're not resettling and you need to turn them over onto their back this is ok, but continue trying to resettle them whilst on their tummy and they'll get used to sleeping in this position.

Ensure lots of playtime and tummy time on the mat during the day to encourage their development and help them master the skill of rolling. It's very normal for any developmental milestone like this to affect sleep, but it does pass as they get better at it.

Q: At the lunchtime nap when I'm resettling my baby, if they have been resettled for 40-60 mins and they finally fall asleep, do I wake them at the suggested wake-up time in the routine? Or can I let them sleep a bit longer seeing as they took a while to resettle?
ANS:
If your baby is still having 3 naps, I suggest letting them have a full sleep cycle of sleep (40-45 mins), then waking them with a happy wake-up and continuing on with your day. You'll most likely need to wake them to squeeze in a third nap, otherwise, they'll most likely be overtired and cranky by bedtime. i.e. Wake them at 3pm to ensure they can fit in a brief 3rd nap at around 4.45pm.

If your baby has dropped to 2 naps, then you can let them sleep for longer to help get them through to bedtime. i.e. Let them sleep until 3.30pm.

Q: We started working on overnight sleep and this technique worked really well. We're now ready to tackle daytime naps. Do we go back to the original timing or continue what we're on overnight?

â€‹ANS: Start back at the original timing you began with, but as your baby will be used to this technique it's ok to progress a bit faster and increase the timings to what they're used to.

Many parents get distressed when their baby brings up milk, but not every spill of milk is a true vomit, and not all refluxed milk means your baby has reflux. In this section, I'll talk you through the different types of vomit and spills and walk through the difference between refluxed milk and a reflux diagnosis.

Reflux exists, but not as commonly as most people think.

Before you continue reading, I want everyone to approach the topics of reflux, reflux diagnosis, and reflux and sleep with caution. A reflux diagnosis in babies is a really serious condition that needs to be treated. Weâ€™ll discuss in this article what I believe to be a widespread misunderstanding of the condition of reflux and an over-diagnosis and, in my opinion, an over-medication of the condition.

Infant reflux has wrongly become the go-to, rapid explainer of unsettled behavior in babies.

A true diagnosis of gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), depending on where you are, is not particularly common. Thereâ€™s some really terrible language we use around babies and newborns that adds to this confusion and leads to overdiagnosis/medication.

The difference between â€œrefluxed milkâ€ and a diagnosis of â€œgastro-oesophageal reflux diseaseâ€ (GORD)

Many people incorrectly refer to small amounts of â€œrefluxed milk,â€ â€œspills,â€ â€œup chucks,â€ or â€œpossetsâ€ of milk as a reflux diagnosis or signs of reflux in babies.

Small spills or possets of milk by a happy, growing baby are completely normal. They donâ€™t cause unsettledness and donâ€™t require specific investigation or management. Nearly all babies will posset milk from time to time (see why babies reflux milk below). Some healthy babies posset LOTS of milk â€“ youâ€™ll identify their parents with a cloth over their shoulder or up-chucked milk down the front of their shirts. These babies are gaining weight and are settled â€“ you may hear me refer to these babies as â€œhappy spitters.â€

Why babies â€˜refluxâ€™ milk

When a baby feeds, the stomach becomes over-stretched, especially if it is full of milk and wind. Any muscle in the body desires to return to its original size and will therefore rebound back, much like an untied balloon deflates rapidly when released.

In babies who reflux a significant amount of milk, the lower esophageal sphincter muscle is often not fully developed and lets the stomach contents back up the esophagus. This can often result in a column of milk rising up the oesophagus (feeding tube) and spilling out, causing your baby to spit up (or â€œrefluxâ€ milk).

TIP: By deflating the stomach with more winding, we can reduce the chance of that rising column of milk.

There are generally 4 types of â€˜vomitâ€™ that need to be defined:

  1. First is a small volume, effortless ejection of milk â€“ a posset.

    • This is described above and causes no distress, no weight loss, no issues at all.
    • It occurs in almost half of all babies, usually begins before 2 months of age, and tends to peak at 4 months.
    • Some babies will posset after every feed â€“ sometimes even hours after a feed.
    • These babies are often described as â€˜happy spitters,â€™ and despite the inconvenience to the parent, the possets are of no concern.
    • No investigations need to be done, and no treatment is necessary.
    • In some ways, thereâ€™s a positive to having â€˜happy spittersâ€™ - they tend to bring wind up very easily and are often the most settled babies in town!

  2. Second is a vomit.

    • This is an ejection of stomach contents, involving retching/gagging and accessory muscles, like the shoulders lifting up.
    • This will empty the stomach, and yes, this milk needs to be replaced.
    • Large vomits occurring infrequently are not problematic, but recurrent vomiting needs to be investigated.

  3. The last type of vomit is a projectile vomit.

    • These occur in the setting of an obstructed stomach, most commonly caused by pyloric stenosis.
    • This is unmissable (the vomit hits the ceiling or the wall behind you) and worsens quicklyâ€”itâ€™s a medical emergency.
    • Bright green vomit (bilious, of any volume) can also be a sign of obstruction and needs urgent medical attention.

  4. Lastly - true reflux.

    • Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease is an uncommon condition, where very frequent milk reflux leads to:
      • Feed refusal
      • Poor growth
      • Bloody vomits
      • Irritability
      • Chronic cough
    • This needs to be checked by a doctor.

The terms â€œrefluxed milkâ€ and a diagnosis of â€œgastro-oesophageal reflux diseaseâ€ (GORD) are used interchangeably, and they shouldnâ€™t be.

Your babyâ€™s reflux may not need any treatment at all. It is important not to medicate a baby for â€œgastroesophageal reflux diseaseâ€ (GERD) if it is not the cause of their unsettled behavior.

A wonderful 2006 study led by Australian pediatricians showed no link between these milk â€˜spillsâ€™ or â€˜possetsâ€™ and symptoms we would see in babies experiencing genuine discomfort, i.e., crying time or back-arching.

â€œRefluxâ€ has become the go-to, rapid explainer of unsettled behavior, becoming synonymous with colic, and it shouldnâ€™t be.

From 2000-2003, there was a 400% increase in the prescribing of anti-reflux medication, yet no reduction in the incidence of colic â€“ which speaks volumes about the true incidence of reflux.

This is dangerous for two simple reasons:

  1. First, the medication prescribed for reflux is not without its side effects.
  2. Second, the true cause of that babyâ€™s unsettled behavior is being missed.

True gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) has very serious symptoms:

  • Weight loss
  • Severe feeding difficulties
  • Bloody vomit
  • Bile (Green or yellow fluid) in vomit
  • Chronic cough, wheeze
  • Aspiration
  • Haematemesis

Babies with these symptoms may need medication or even surgery â€“ itâ€™s a rare but serious diagnosis.

Silent reflux is a myth.

Many incorrectly refer to spillage or possets of milk as reflux. But even worse is the diagnosis of silent reflux â€“ which is a massive myth!!

Some believe an unsettled baby who does not vomit or posset may suffer from â€˜silent reflux.â€™ However, this is not a medical diagnosis.

Anti-reflux medications have risks & side effects

From 2000-2003, there was a 400% increase in the prescribing of anti-reflux medication to infant reflux, yet no reduction in the incidence of colic â€“ which speaks volumes about the true incidence of reflux.

FAQ: My GP or Pediatrician has prescribed reflux medication, and after reading this, Iâ€™m now questioning whether my baby should actually be taking it?

Before you do anything, talk to your GP or pediatrician so that they can assess your baby, looking for true symptoms of GORD. The advice in blogs is only general in nature & every baby requires individualized care.

It's not always reflux!

Q. When are babies able to burp themselves and the winding process isnâ€™t a thing anymore?

ANS: This can last for many months but babies slowly get better at winding themselves, the longer they spend upright. Also, as they take larger volumes of solids - the need for winding subsides.

Q. How do I manage burping when my baby is pulling off frequently?
ANS: The most common reason a baby pulls off after a few short sucks is due to the gastro-colic reflex, as highlighted in the program. Trapped wind from the previous feed causes cramping in the colon, as soon as the stomach starts to fill with milk from the current feed. While you may need to offer a quick burp each time they fall off the breast/bottle, itâ€™s important to understand that your baby is telling us they needed to burp more at the previous feed. Hopefully, when they are fully winded at this feed, youâ€™ll enter into a nice rhythm/cycle and see them sucking for longer periods of time at future feeds, so this becomes less of a problem.

Q. Do I burp after each boob/bottle suck?
ANS: Yes itâ€™s important to offer a burp after each side or break during a bottle feed. The goal is to get up as much wind as possible to prevent unsettledness in the coming hours. You donâ€™t have to offer the full 15 mins of winding after each small break, but at least offer the full 15 mins at the end of the feed.

Q. Is there a certain number of burps we should be aiming for in a feeding session?
ANS: There's no magic number of burps as some are larger than others. That's why I like to devote a certain time period of time to winding.

Q. Do certain foods make breastfed babies more gassy?
ANS: They certainly do! Things that make us gassy will also make babies gassy. Like broccoli or beans. Babies also sometimes struggle with spice, garlic or onion.

Q. We only get a maximum of 1-2 burps per 15 mins. If this happens in the first 5-10 mins can we stop there or still need to continue for the full 15?
ANS: The answer is yes - always respond to your baby. If they bring up all their wind in the first five minutes then there's no need to continue winding for another ten minutes.

Q. How important is the 2 minutes down 1 minute up?
ANS: Similar to the question above, always respond to your baby, if you are achieving great burps with say 1 minute down and 30 seconds up and your baby is showing no signs of discomfort from trapped wind then thatâ€™s great. If youâ€™re struggling to get burps up then the 2 minutes down 1 minute up for 15 minutes is really important.

Q. Should the burp sound be loud & obvious?
ANS: Your baby burps can be loud like Homer Simpson or a small whimper, all are bringing up air but definitely not the same amount. Itâ€™s important to wind thoroughly using the active winding technique and to always be trying to read your baby for signs of trapped wind, remember these may not be immediate and youâ€™ll often see the associated unsettledness in the hours to come.

Q. Is a little spew / spit up classed as a â€œburpâ€?
ANS: Yes - sometimes a big bubble of gas can carry a small posset above it, this is no problem (other than the mess!).

Q. The active winding method requires baby to be horizontal, but my baby squirms and cries when horizontal after a feed then when picked up has vomited. Is there an alternative to having the baby lay fully flat horizontal?
ANS: You can keep your baby upright for a few minutes, before beginning the method. When flat, try cycling the legs, rubbing the tummy, interacting playfully or using a dummy, to try to get them as calm as possible. Remember, small possets don't matter, as long as baby is gaining good weight.

Q. My baby is so hard to burp, I'm lucky to get one in 15 mins. It's making night wakings so much longer and I'm exhausted. Any advice?
ANS: Some babies are certainly harder to wind than others. If your active winding technique is right and you're devoting time to it after every feed but still not getting more burps after a week, I'd consider adding a colic mix to help the wind out more easily.

Q. What colic mix do you recommend?
ANS: As a paediatrician, I remain brand-agnostic when it comes to medicines, homeopathics and listed pharmaceuticals. There are a number of different products on the market, including simethicone, dicyclomine, belladonna, hyoscyamine and dozens more. Itâ€™s important to discuss these with your childâ€™s doctor or paediatrician before administering any, due to potential side effects.

Q. Can nipple shields increase the amount of air my baby swallows and make them more uncomfortable?
ANS: No, if your baby is attaching correctly around the shield this should not be any different to a bottle or a breastfed baby - that is, they will all take in some air and burping them after every sucking period is essential. I always recommend hand expressing some milk into the top of the shield so that the first mouthful is milk not air.

Q. Can I burp a sleeping baby?
ANS: Iâ€™m so glad you asked - the answer is YES! Many parents particularly in the first 6 weeks find their baby is showing tired signs as before they have finished their active winding periodsâ€¦and they know there are still a burp or two more they need to get up. My advice here is to swaddle them up, get them into the cot lying flat, if they are dozy or fully asleep you can still pick them up gently after a couple of minutes and get that last burp or so out. I often did the late night 10/11pm feed. Iâ€™d put them down, go clean my teeth and then come back to get that last burpâ€¦itâ€™s sooo satisfying!!

Q. Is the cot mattress too soft to use active winding technique?
ANS: For the full active winding method the cot mattress isnâ€™t ideal - but if itâ€™s just for the last burp as your baby drifts off to sleep, then itâ€™s absolutely fine - see my notes above.

Q. My baby is very upset during the 2 mins down on the mat. Is it ok to use a dummy/pacifier to help soothe him during this time?
ANS: Yes, it is ok to use a dummy during the 2 mins horizontal time while winding to help keep your baby calm. However, remove the dummy before bringing them up to the vertical position. Every few days try without the dummy during winding to see how your baby goes

This age group marks a huge change in how your baby is developing in terms of their gross motor skills. Babies between 4-8 months will become more aware of their body, often learning to roll back to front and front to back consistently, sit up unaided, commando crawl and some will also crawl on all fours and pull themselves to the standing position.

All this development means their brains are on overdrive and this can have a big impact on sleep. If your baby is waking during the night to have a â€˜cot partyâ€™ and are quite happy practising their new skill then the best thing you can do is just leave them be. Usually, babies will get tired and pop themselves back to sleep. If they get upset then that is when itâ€™s a good time to start using your settling technique to teach them itâ€™s time to go back to sleep.

As weâ€™ve discussed throughout this program, once your baby is rolling itâ€™s no longer safe to have them swaddled and you need to transition them to sleeping with their arms free. Always be sure to place your baby down for their sleeps on their back, however, if they roll themselves onto their tummy and are content in that position, then itâ€™s ok to leave them like that. If your baby becomes upset or â€˜stuckâ€™ in a position they arenâ€™t happy with theyâ€™ll be sure to let you know about it and you can help them return to their back.

Encourage the practice of any new skill during the day. The more they do it during the day, the quicker they will get the hang of it and be less likely to get â€˜stuckâ€™ or bothered during a sleep.

Iâ€™ve seen thousands of babies over the years, brought to me due to concerns about dropping weight centiles. Itâ€™s a very necessary thing to be reviewed by a doctor, because dropping weight centiles - and even more concerning, dropping weight - can be a sign of poor growth and possible underlying problems.

Itâ€™s very distressing for parents, but itâ€™s important to know that it can also be a very normal phenomenon. Many babies might be putting on weight adequately, but dropping centiles from a birth centile - for example, 40th - to a 6-week centile of 25th. Very often, this is what I refer to as a weight correction (see section on weight correction in 2.0 Little Baby).

When in utero, the babyâ€™s weight is determined by the function of the placenta, adequate intake through the umbilical cord and the motherâ€™s blood sugar levels. Babies can sometimes be born larger - or smaller - than expected. But once the baby is born, that sugar supply drops and theyâ€™re more able to regulate their calorie intake, they are bound to drop their weight centile accordingly. Similarly, babies born smaller due to a poorly functioning placenta or umbilical cord will often display excellent â€˜catch-upâ€™ growth and increase centiles accordingly.

The point is that there are many factors at play that determine the birth-weight of a baby and therefore the initial centile. But that may not be the â€˜genetically predeterminedâ€™ (or likely) centile that baby was always going to be on. As they achieve a â€˜correctionâ€™ in their weight centiles, we often see them gaining weight - but dropping centiles. Once reviewed by a doctor, you can trust that this is ok and not a cause for concern in most babies.

Once the weight correction is complete, babies tend to oscillate around a certain centile but generally continue to grow quite consistently. If we watch their centiles too closely however, usually by measuring weight too frequently, babies often appear to be reaching a plateau or dropping centiles again.

Serial (frequent, regular) weight measurements can often induce much anxiety. Once the baby has realised their â€˜genetic centileâ€™ then they often shift between 10 centile points above/below this over time. This is because babies go through periods of â€˜rapid growthâ€™ (less interest in food, smaller volumes consumed, more sleep, marked increase in length, weight plateau) and periods of â€˜energy storageâ€™ (high food intake, increase weight, less sleep). Babies grow like an accordion - first they grow â€˜outâ€™ and then they grow â€˜upâ€™ - once we understand this, we do not stress about a week of poor weight gain, because we trust that next weekâ€™s will likely be far better.

Also take into consideration your babyâ€™s energy intake and output. A baby who has just learned to crawl, for example, might be moving more than ever, expending a huge amount of energy and this might explain a brief drop on the centile chart.

If you have noticed a significant centile drop or multiple centile reductions over many weeks, have your child reviewed by a doctor.

As discussed, swaddling helps turn on your babyâ€™s calming reflex and protects them from the startle reflex, so un-swaddling too soon can cause an increase in sleep disturbances. There are no strict guidelines on when to unswaddle your baby, and many babies will wriggle free of their swaddle independently.

All babies should be unswaddled by 6 months or earlier if they have begun rolling from back to front. Once rolling, it becomes unsafe to continue swaddling them.

  • 30% of babies are unswaddled by 4 months
  • 50% by 6 months
  • 20% need to be unswaddled in the 6th month for their safety

Tips on weaning from the swaddle:

  • There are many transitional swaddles available that help make the process easier. This means you might be able to do one arm free at a time.
  • Start with just one arm out for day naps first.
  • If baby wakes after one sleep cycle, try rolling them onto their side, which gently holds their arm down for them, and resettle them. Once asleep, be sure to turn them to their back.
  • Once baby is sleeping well during the day with one arm out, try one arm out overnight.
  • Give baby a few days of one arm out during the day and overnight, then begin to try both arms out for day and nighttime sleep.
  • Once both arms are out, you can begin putting baby in a sleeping bag (appropriately TOG rated for the season).
  • The third nap of the day is the hardest to achieve, so if you need to keep swaddling for this nap a little while longer, thatâ€™s okay.
  • For the arm(s) that are out, if your baby is unsettled, try putting socks or mittens on their hands, as they are used to the familiar feeling of material on their hands.

Lesson Name: What is a Baby or Infant Growth Chart?
Lesson Content:
An infant growth chart helps you, your doctor, maternal nurses and other health professionals keep track of how your baby is growing.Growth charts record changes in your babyâ€™s measurements, including their:

  • Length (height)
  • Weight
  • Head circumference

These measurements will be recorded on your babyâ€™s physical and/or digital records.Your babyâ€™s growth is a good indicator of their overall health, nutrition and development.


â€‹

Like us, babies come in all shapes and sizes. Centile charts work simply by comparing your babyâ€™s growth with other babies of the same age â€“ the charts differ by gender (different charts exist for certain medical conditions too). 

Baby centile and infant growth charts are usually calculated using the World Health Organisationâ€™s growth standards (some example charts below).

You will see the percentile lines on the chart running parallel to each other. The percentile lines include 5%, 10%, 25%, 50%, 75%, 90% and 95%.

Example 1:  
If a childâ€™s weight is at the 50th percentile line, that means that out of 100 children of that age, 50 will be bigger than they are, and 50 smaller.

Example 2:
If a childâ€™s weight is in the 75th percentile, that means that your baby is bigger than 75 children and smaller than 25, compared with 100 children their own age.

Example 3:  
A baby on the 5th percentile weighs less than 95% of other babies of that age.

When it comes to measuring our babies on these curves, itâ€™s important to remember some babies will always be small, and others will always be large. 

You havenâ€™t mastered parenting if your baby is in the 90th percentile, and youâ€™re not a failure if your baby is in the 10th percentile! Where they sit is less important than their rate of growth.

All babies grow at different rates, and â€˜normalâ€™ growth varies. 

â€‹

The thing your health care professional will be looking for is that your baby continues to grow at a similar rate â€“ this is often referred to as â€˜following the curveâ€™. 

BUT... their growth wonâ€™t always follow a smooth linear path on these curves, so be sure to put the growth charts and centiles into context. 

Babies and infants will often bounce up and down slightly on the growth charts, depending on:

  • feeding issues, 
  • illnesses and
  • growth spurts
Donâ€™t obsess about every movement on your babyâ€™s growth chart. 

When there is a persistent downward trend, this should always be investigated by a health professional.

The discomfort of teething is mostly caused by the tooth progressing through the gum, not the actual eruption. Itâ€™s really important if irritability and discomfort are ongoing and you donâ€™t see any teeth come through that you get your paediatrician or GP to review â€“ in my experience, teething is blamed for a LOT of unsettled behaviour when itâ€™s not the actual cause.

Excessive drooling: Increased saliva production is a common teething sign, which can sometimes lead to a rash on the chin.

Irritability: Teething can make your baby irritable, fussy, and prone to mood swings.

Chewing and biting: Babies may chew on objects or try to bite things to relieve the pressure on their gums.

Gum swelling and sensitivity: You may notice redness, swelling, or tenderness in your babyâ€™s gums.

Sleep disturbances: Unfortunately, other teething symptoms include an extra fussy baby that can have disruptions to their regular bedtime routine. Baby wakes because teething discomfort often peaks at night, leading to disrupted sleep patterns for babies and parents â€“ the great news is each tooth is only a 24-hour cycle, so itâ€™s relatively short-lived (I appreciate it doesnâ€™t feel like this when youâ€™re in the thick of it).

Loose bowels and associated nappy rash: New teeth coming through can cause hypersalivation (excessive drooling) and therefore diarrhoea and loose bowels. Teething itself doesn't cause nappy rash, but the sensitive skin around their bottoms is more likely to be affected by diarrhoea and loose bowels.

Note: Teething will NOT increase a baby's temperature above 38 degrees. Do not attribute a temperature >38 degrees to teething, there is likely a medical cause that should be evaluated.

Lesson Name: Tips to Help Your Teething Baby
Lesson Content:
TIP 1: Chilled teething rings or teething toysGive your baby a clean, chilled teething ring, some teething toys, or a chilled damp washcloth to gnaw on. The cold sensation can reduce inflammation, help numb their gums, and provide relief. Ensure the toy or teething ring is age-appropriate and free from small parts to prevent it from becoming a choking hazard for your child.

Pro tip: If youâ€™re using a washcloth option, soak it in breastmilk or formula, make a ball, and tie a rubber band around the middle so they have something to hold onto.

TIP 2: Gentle gum massage
Wash your hands thoroughly and use a clean finger to massage your babyâ€™s gums gently. This can help alleviate some of the discomfort and provide soothing relief where their teeth are coming through their gums.

TIP 3: Pain relief options
Consult your babyâ€™s paediatrician or doctor about pain relief medications that are safe for your babyâ€™s age. Always follow your doctorâ€™s recommendations regarding dosage and usage.

TIP 4: Dietary adjustments
If your baby has started solid foods, offer cold and soft foods like yogurt, pureed fruit, or chilled cucumber. The coolness can provide relief to sore gums.

TIP 5: Babyâ€™s bedtime routine
Establish a calming bedtime routine to help with nighttime fussiness that includes activities such as a warm bath, soft lullabies, and cuddling. A consistent routine signals to your baby that itâ€™s time to sleep.

TIP 6: Distraction
Engage your baby in gentle play or story time before bedtime to divert their attention from teething discomfort. Distraction can help them relax and fall asleep more easily.

TIP 7: Comfort items
If your baby has a favourite stuffed animal or blanket, make sure itâ€™s within reach. These comfort items can provide a sense of security. Please ensure this is age-appropriate from a SIDS/safety perspective.

TIP 8: Monitor nighttime nappy changes
If your baby is in discomfort due to teething, try to minimise nighttime nappy changes to avoid waking them unnecessarily. Use high-absorbency nappies to reduce the chances of leaks.

TIP 9: Consult your paediatrician or doctor
If your babyâ€™s teething discomfort is severe and persists for an extended period, or if you have concerns about their sleep, donâ€™t hesitate to consult your paediatrician or healthcare provider who can also help your baby. They can provide guidance and tips and rule out any other potential issues.

While many of our parents used over the counter teething gels, and if you have older children you may have used it on them, recent guidelines have changed significantly when it comes to teething gels: 

  • Recent literature suggests that teething gels (especially those containing lidocaine) are not recommended due to the possible dosing / toxicity effects.
  • The evidence and literature is also not clear as to the efficacy of the gel in actually managing teething pain  
  • It is also not clear how much of the gel is being swallowed (as this is hard to control) by a baby and so there is concern about the potential adverse effects and toxicity. 
  • The Australian and New Zealand Society of Paediatric Dentistry also do not recommend teething gels as a solution to teething pain and a recent literature review (2020) in the Journal of Paediatrics and Child Health also recommend against the use of the teething gels containing lidocaine
  • My colleagues in the US (American Academy of Paediatrics) also do not recommend teething gels for babies either

Why babies refuse bottles

Bottle refusal can be extremely stressful for both parent and baby.
I often have parents come to me in desperation as theyâ€™re heading back to work in a couple of weeks and their baby is refusing to take a bottle.

The good news is that there are ways to help your baby learn to take a bottle while not impacting your breastfeeding journey or milk supply.

Bottle refusal is more common in older babies and happens for a number of reasons:

Younger babies (<4 months)

  • Bottle refusal is far less common in this age group.
  • Babies under 4 months still have their sucking reflex, which means that anything that goes into their mouth they will try to suck.
  • The problem here is that parents can have a great experience, become complacent, and weeks or months can go by before trying the bottle again.

Older babies (>4 months)

  • Bottle refusal can be common in this age group.
  • After 4 months, your baby will lose that reflex, so sucking becomes voluntary.
  • Older babies are more likely to refuse because itâ€™s unfamiliar:
    • The milk can taste different (even expressed breast milk).
    • The flow is different.
    • The feel of the teat is different from a motherâ€™s nipple.

Lesson Name: Introducing Bottles â€“ A How to Guide
Lesson Content:
Once they are taking a bottle well, I recommend giving 1 bottle every 2-3 days to keep it familiar.

Who should be the one offering the bottle?
Youâ€™ve probably had LOTS of advice about who should give the bottle, and that youâ€™ll have more success if you let the non-breastfeeding partner or another caregiver offer it.

Well, this definitely isnâ€™t always the case!!
Because babies, particularly older babies, need time and practice to feel comfortable with the bottle, the best person to have those practice sessions with is their main caregiver, who is often the breastfeeding mother.
This is also usually the most practical as they are the ones spending the majority of their time with the baby.

The importance of remaining calm and relaxed as a parent
Itâ€™s really important that whoever is offering the bottle isnâ€™t stressed or anxious - remember that our BABIES DRINK MORE THAN MILK.

Your baby will pick up on all your emotions.
This isnâ€™t to underplay bottle rejection - the thought your baby may not get enough milk is a seriously daunting thought for any parent, especially if you have no other option.
BUTâ€¦ I want you to approach offering a bottle with every bit of zen-like positive energy you can muster.

  • Relax your shoulders
  • Take a huge breath in
  • â€¦and exhale
  • Wriggle your bum
  • Smile to yourself
  • Use a calm, even voice as you talk to your baby

If you find yourself tensing up, getting flustered, and speaking in a shrill or panicked voice, repeat all these steps again - being calm as you offer the bottle as a parent is one of the number one things we can do.
Even if this isnâ€™t how you feel at all - fake it until you make it!

How to introduce a bottle to an older baby who is refusing

First remember:
If a baby feels overwhelmed or unsafe, they wonâ€™t take the bottle.

The trick is to get them comfortable with:

  1. The bottle itself
  2. The person giving it
  3. Making sure that person (usually a primary caregiver) isnâ€™t feeling anxious or stressed, as your baby will pick up on that.

Tip 1: Start with introducing an EMPTY bottle with LOTS of practice sessions

  • Including it in some playtime is a great idea
  • Try to keep breastfeeding away from this time
  • DONâ€™T cradle them like you would if you were breastfeeding them

Tip 3: See which position your baby prefers

  • Try not to bring the bottle straight into their face
  • Bring the bottle gently up from below their chin



Tip 4: Let the bottle tickle their lips or chin

  • Donâ€™t jam it into their mouth/throat
  • If your baby opens their mouth, gently let the teat be guided upwards
  • Guiding it up towards their upper palate is less overwhelming and less likely to make them gag.


Tip 5: Encourage a little suck

  • And repeat steps 1-4 at least a few times a day

Tip 6: Donâ€™t tip the bottle until they are relaxed and comfortable

  • Once they seem comfortable with the bottle, you can tip the bottle horizontal so it offers them some breastmilk or formula.

How to protect breastfeeding and prevent breast refusalSome babies will have no problems taking a bottle once they get used to it. It can be easy for babies to enjoy having bottles - some can even become bottle obsessed.

Your baby can get lazy with a bottle:

  • It is often easier to feed from a bottle compared to a breast
  • The milk simply trickles out of the teat without having to work hard for it.

Just as we donâ€™t want bottle refusal, we also donâ€™t want babies to develop breast refusal.
Thatâ€™s why offering just 1 bottle every 1-3 days will keep it familiar, but also reinforces breastfeeding if this is how theyâ€™re fed the majority of the time.

How to protect your breast milk supply while offering bottles
To protect your supply, you need to make sure you have a pumping session in lieu of any missed breastfeeds.
E.g., if the non-breastfeeding parent was to give a bottle at the 10/11pm feed, the breastfeeding parent could express at 8/8.30pm and then go to bed.

If youâ€™re concerned about supply, you may also want to consider expressing after a breastfeed in the early morning, as this is when supply is at its greatest.

Itâ€™s always helpful to keep a stash of breastmilk in the fridge/freezer when offering bottles.

Best teat shape to choose and which ones to avoid

While itâ€™s tempting to buy every type of bottle and teat when trying to get your baby to take a bottle, itâ€™s best to stick to just a couple and avoid overwhelming your baby.

The best shape of teat has two features:

  • A gradual slope


A narrow base

Which teat flow to choose for which baby

Choosing the right flow rate is incredibly important.

  • Too slow and your baby will become frustrated.
  • Too fast (both breast and bottle) and your baby can gulp, splutter, you might see milk spilling from the sides of the mouth, gagging, coughing, and pushing the teat out.

Under 4 months old:

  • Itâ€™s best to try a slow flow teat.
  • Or one marked 0-3 months or size 0-1.

Over 4 months old:

  • Try a medium teat or stage 2, or one marked 3-6 months.
  • You could also try one marked for 6 months plus.
  • If it is too slow, your baby will be frustrated and less likely to take the bottle.

Tip: Most anti-colic bottles/teats are slow flow.

Paced bottle feeding is a way to feed babies their bottles at a pace that is more similar to breastfeeding.

When your baby is breastfeeding, they will:

  • Have a few sucks, then stop.
  • Wait for a letdown.
  • Continue to suck and swallow.

With breastfeeding, the flow slows after a letdown and then picks up again with the next letdown, with most feeds having multiple letdowns.

With a bottle feed, there is less of a slow/fast flow and more of a constant flow, sometimes overwhelming a baby if they're not used to it.

To give a bottle using paced bottle feeding:

Step 1: Keep the teat horizontal, not on the diagonal or upright, as milk just drips out in these positions. This angle is more like breastfeeding, and the baby can control the flow.



Step 2: Allow some milk to fill half the teat and let your baby continue to suck.

Step 3: When your baby pauses, drop the angle of the bottle down to give the baby a break. When they show signs of wanting more or sucking begins again, angle the bottle horizontally, fill the teat about halfway with milk, and continue.


Don't forget to give your baby some breaks and burp them thoroughly during the feed too.

Tummy time is wonderful for promoting development, interacting with your baby, and enjoying some time without a focus on feeding or winding. Some babies, however, strongly dislike lying on their stomachs, and if this is the case with your baby, donâ€™t feel the need to force it. Plenty of babies have very minimal time spent on their stomachs and still develop perfectly normally.

For babies who dislike tummy time, itâ€™s worthwhile revisiting it every few weeks, as they tend to tolerate it better as they get older.

The History of Tummy Time:

Historically, SIDS rates were disturbingly high. When the American Academy of Pediatrics launched their Back-to-Sleep campaign in 1994, there was a phenomenal 50% reduction in SIDS episodes. While this was undoubtedly successful and should never be challenged, placing children on their backs resulted in some unwanted side effects.

The first was flat-head syndrome (discussed later), and the next was delayed gross motor development. Babies spent less time on their stomachs, pushing up, strengthening their back, shoulder, and neck muscles, which delayed the strength and coordination required for sitting, standing, etc.

Importantly, though, researchers who conducted the 1998 study found that back-sleepers eventually developed their motor skills just fine:

â€œAll infants achieved all milestones within the accepted normal age range,â€ they wrote.

Another study published that same year reached a similar conclusionâ€”that although babies who spent less time on their tummies developed motor skills more slowly, the discrepancies didnâ€™t last.

And in a 2008 study, researchers reported that babies who were given more awake tummy timerolled and crawled earlier than babies who were given less, but they didnâ€™t learn to sit or walk any sooner.

Interestingly, researchers have also found ties between when babies develop gross motor skills and when they develop certain cognitive skillsâ€”which raises questions over whether tummy time might also make kids â€˜smarter.â€™

Studies have found that infants who are able to sit up have a more advanced understanding of the three-dimensional nature of objects, perhaps because they can more easily explore and inspect their toys.

Babies who have spent more time crawling and walking, regardless of their age, also have better spatial memory skills. And a 2014 study found that babies often learn to walk right before they develop language skillsâ€”so if they learn to walk later, they might talk later too.

So, yes: Tummy time is good â€” but you donâ€™t need to overly fret about it. And keep in mind that just a minute or two â€” even just 30 seconds â€” of tummy time will add up if you do it regularly.

If your baby really hates it, try placing them on their tummy on your chest instead of on the floor.

Dummies are a great tool for assisting babies to settle and sleep. 

However, sometimes dummies can interfere with sleep and parents find themselves waking countless times during the night to replace the dummy. In these circumstances, I recommend ditching it.

Babies aren't able to 'find and replace' their own dummies until closer to 7 months old. This can mean a lot of interrupted sleep getting up and constantly replacing a dummy during naps and overnight sleep if your baby is unable to link sleep cycles without it in their mouth.

If dummy use is affecting your baby's sleep and they are under 5 months, I recommend ditching the dummy. If they are over 5 months, then it might be worth keeping it and starting to teach them to 'find and replace' it themselves.

Ditching it past 6 months can be a difficult mission as the attachment is often very strong.

Remember - it's only a problem if it's a problem for you!

Babies canâ€™t learn to find and replace their dummy until around 7 months old, so that can mean a lot of broken sleep waiting for your baby to learn this skill. If your baby is under 5 months old, I recommend ditching the dummy if it is impacting negatively on their sleep. The good news is that if sleep has been thrown off track, then getting rid of the dummy can only help things, and yours and babyâ€™s sleep shouldnâ€™t be impacted too much more than it already is.

How to ditch the dummy:
Â· When settling your baby for a nap and at bedtime, watch their awake times and tired signs and be sure to get them into bed within 10 mins of showing these signs.
Â· Timing is important for all sleeps but especially when ditching the dummy, as we donâ€™t want to pop baby down too early and not have enough drive to sleep, but also donâ€™t want to be dealing with an overtired baby either.
Â· Settle your baby with no dummy, place them in their cot/bassinet using your settling technique.
Â· If your baby is still awake and upset 10 mins later, then go ahead and help them to sleep with a pat/cuddle/rock/etc.
Â· In the first few days, if you need to resettle your baby (i.e., if they wake early from a nap), try your best to help them back to sleep but do offer the dummy if all else fails. We want to ensure we keep on top of sleep and donâ€™t have a baby that is too overtired.
Â· After the first few days, however, ditch the dummy altogether as your baby should be getting used to settling without it now.
Â· If you have successfully ditched the dummy, there is nothing to say you canâ€™t give it back to them if needed when unwell or uncomfortable (for example, during teething). Try to delay this until they are older and can learn to find and replace it themselves.

Lesson Name: Teaching Your Baby to Find and Replace their Dummy
Lesson Content:
If your baby still has their dummy at 6 months old, I donâ€™t recommend ditching it. Their association with it is probably too strong, and it is best to keep it and start teaching them to find and replace it themselves.

Finding and replacing their own dummy begins with showing them how to pick it up themselves and pop it in their own mouth the right way. You might have to physically put their hand on their dummy for them and guide their hand to their mouth in the correct way. Make it into a game during the day to allow for lots of practice. The sooner they are able to find and replace their own dummy, the quicker they will be able to self-soothe when they wake from a day nap or during the night.

Under 7 months, I recommend placing lots of dummies in their cot; imagine how hard it would be finding a small dummy in a bed in complete darkness! I also recommend introducing a comforter that they can become familiar with and most likely attach to. If your baby is taking a dummy, I recommend a comforter that you can attach multiple dummies to. Wear the comforter down your top so it takes on your smell, which will make it more appealing to your baby.

Follow SIDS guidelines and keep it out of the cot until 7 months old, however, they can still have it in the pram, car, or at playtime to become familiar with it.

When your baby is around 5-6 months old I recommend introducing a comforter during their play time. It is not yet safe to put in their cot for sleeps yet, but letting them become familiar with it will help it become a positive sleep prop when they reach 7 months old. A comforter could be a small handkerchief sized soft blanket or toy. Wear it down your top to help it take on your smell, this will help it be more comforting for your baby. If your baby takes a dummy, then as mentioned above, introduce a comforter that you can attach multiple dummies to so they can find them more easily during sleep time. 


From 7 months old, in accordance with SIDS guidelines, I recommend popping the comforter in bed with them for all sleeps. It will quickly become a positive sleep association. Comforters are great as they are portable and small and can quickly calm an unsettled baby as they grow older. Some personal advice -- have a few spare comforters on hand, in case one is lost or needing a good wash!

A bit of preparation can go a long way when organising your travel. 

Here are my top tips for flying with kids:

Itâ€™s easier (& cheaper) when they are younger:

Younger babies often sleep really well on aeroplanes because of the vibrations and white noise effect of the engines. As they get older and more mobile it does get harder to get a baby to sleep soundly on an aeroplane, and having them sleep on you might be the only thing that works. Again, this is ok and wonâ€™t cause any long term habits.

Airline bassinets are for babies under the age of two (but in my experience once they are over the age of one they can have a lot of trouble fitting in these and sleeping comfortably) There are some great universal covers you can buy that fit over both prams and plane bassinets that can ben incredibly handy at recreating their sleep environment (particularly when the cabin lights are on).

Should I fly during the day or night?

Depending on the length of the flight and age of your baby or child, there are pros and cons whether you decide to fly during the day or overnight. Sometimes there may not be a choice.

Flying during the day will create less stress about your baby or child sleeping and may be easier in terms of stress on the parent.

However, flying overnight can mean your child will be less restless and wonâ€™t need to be occupied if they sleep well.

Adjusting to new timezones:

Regarding the adjustment to new time-zones when travelling long distances, children who have sleeps during the day will often adjust far quicker than adults, due to the cyclical nature of their melatonin surges.

If possible, allow 1-2 days of relaxing after arrival, in order to adjust â€“ you will probably benefit more than the kids!

The day after arrival, try to wake your baby around their usual time, even if they have had a broken nightâ€™s sleep because of jetlag. This is the best thing you can do to help get your baby acclimatised to the new time zone.

Medications & flying:

If electing to use medication as a sleep aid for children, it should NEVER be tried for the first time on a flight. Speak to your doctor or pharmacist and trial the medication weeks earlier to ensure thereâ€™s no allergic reaction or unexpected response; you donâ€™t want to find this out mid-flight!

When you arrive try & stick to your usual routine:

On arrival at your destination, the most important thing is to try and stick to your babyâ€™s regular routine, without any stress if itâ€™s difficult to adhere to, assisted naps are completely acceptable!

On any holiday, there will be days where routine is thrown off and this is ok. If you are out and about then offer your baby their naps at their usual times. If they havenâ€™t slept well during the day, then try your best to bring bedtime earlier to compensate.

Naps on the go will also be inevitable, such as pram or carrier naps.

Recreate their sleep environment as much as possible

When setting up a sleep environment that is unfamiliar to your baby/toddler, try to recreate their usual sleep environment as much as possible.

Take their cot sheet and sleeping bags from home so it smells familiar, blackout the windows the best you can, take a portable white noise machine or download an app on your phone and take any comforters/toys your baby is used to sleeping with.

If your baby is used to sleeping in their own room at home, then try your best to continue this while on holiday. Similarly, if your baby is used to sleeping next to you or in your bedroom at home, then continue this where possible.

Often small spaces like hotel rooms or tiny apartments are necessary when travelling, in this case â€“ products such as a blackout cot tent/canopy can be so helpful, as you donâ€™t have to blackout the entire room at nap times.

Returning home:

When you return home, try to get your baby back into their usual routine within 24-48 hours.

Depending on the time difference of where you have travelled to, your baby might take longer to return to their usual routine, but just do your best and use any settling techniques available to you.

Long car trips with babies and young children

Long car trips with babies and young children can be very daunting for parents, and itâ€™s understandable that some people want to avoid them altogether. However, long car trips donâ€™t have to be painful â€“ as long as you plan properly.

Here are some of my favorite tips for traveling long distances with babies and children:

Make a list & ensure the trip is a team effort:

  • Donâ€™t leave one person responsible for everything. Have a packing list that both parents tick off together.
  • If this is your first big trip with a baby or kids, remember itâ€™s not as simple as packing when you were just a couple. Allow yourself plenty of time to pack the car or do the majority the day/night before. Whatever time you need to leave requires a half-hour window to get on the road â€“ a dirty diaper or toilet demand just as youâ€™re locking the front door is comically inevitable!
  • Share the driving as much as possible.
  • Be kind to each other and laugh â€“ itâ€™s much better than arguing.

Take into account your babyâ€™s routine when planning the trip:

  • If confident driving in the evening, consider leaving after youâ€™ve done their entire dinner and bath routine. They will have enough sleep debt built up to make it easier for them to fall asleep. But make sure you switch drivers regularly and get enough rest yourselves, so youâ€™re not driving drowsy.
  • A different option is heading to bed early the night before and leaving incredibly early in the morning, like 4-5 am. Transferring them into the car in their pajamas can work â€“ this way you can get a few hours under your belt before they really wake up in time for breakfast.
  • Another good time to leave is at nap time. Include lots of playtime and tire them out before jumping in the car so they can sleep for the first leg of the trip.
  • Keep feed and meal times the same as what theyâ€™re used to â€“ use meal times as a good chance for everyone to stop & stretch their legs. Donâ€™t be in a hurry to arrive at your destination, as this puts undue pressure on you and you lose the opportunity to make the journey a fun part of the holiday.
  • If your baby hasnâ€™t slept well, then try to have a quiet day when you arrive at your destination so they can catch up and get back on track.
  • Consider an early bedtime if your baby hasnâ€™t slept well in the car.

Focus on recreating their sleep environment:

  • Sun shades for the windows are essential.
  • For younger babies, purchasing a breathable blackout cover to put over the car seat encourages a longer nap.
  • Continue to use some portable white noise, although sometimes just the sound and vibration of the car engine is enough to put babies to sleep.
  • Use any comforters or dummies they usually have, and make sure you have numerous replacements that are easily accessible.

Keeping them occupied:

  • Make regular stops to allow your baby to have some car-free time. No matter what their age, let them move their bodies and have tummy time, practice crawling, sitting, standing, or walking.
  • Introduce some new toys during the trip. Different teething toys, soft books, and sensory toys will help pass the time.
  • For toddlers and older kids, try and plan stops near playgrounds.
  • Childrenâ€™s audiobooks/stories or playlists can be enjoyable for those in the back seatâ€¦ listening to the Frozen soundtrack on repeat may not be enjoyable for you (!), so create time where you can listen to your own podcasts, audiobooks, or radio.

Pack healthy snacks & drinks:

  • Remember to do this for you and the kids â€“ itâ€™s a long day for everyone, and eating well will help you all feel better at the other end of the trip. (Breastfeeding mothers in particular need to make sure they stay hydrated and well-fed.)
  • Even if you plan to stop and buy lunch, pack plenty of healthy snacks for along the way.
  • If youâ€™re passing food or snacks back to toddlers or kids in the back seat, always supervise closely to avoid choking hazards.
  • Give snacks in small portions rather than large lunchboxes â€“ this avoids the whole lot falling at their feet, as has happened to all of us!
  • Never feed a rear-facing child where you canâ€™t supervise them eating.
  • Ensure everyone has a water bottle and avoid sugary drinks, as these may give your kids energy you canâ€™t easily run off!

Have the things you need accessible:

  • This may sound obvious, but make sure everything you need â€“ nappies, wipes, change mats, outfit changes, toys, snacks, water bottles, etc. â€“ is all easy to access. Itâ€™s incredibly inconvenient when the one thing you want is at the back of the car under three suitcases!
  • If you think youâ€™ll arrive close to bedtime, make sure portacots, sleep monitors, any bedding, and pajamas/sleepsuits, etc. are easy to pull out of the car. That way, you donâ€™t have to unpack every suitcase when you arrive. Once the kids are asleep, you can unpack the car properly.

Remember: Babies and kids drink more than milk, so if youâ€™re anxious and cranky, they will feed off this. Try and make the car trip as enjoyable for the whole family as possible. Be well prepared, stay safe, and donâ€™t sweat the small stuff. Broken routines will rapidly return once the journey is over and the real holiday begins.

Happy holidays!

Being on the same page as parents is really important when it comes to not just sleep training but how you plan to raise your kids as a couple. 

Giving your baby a consistent message from both caregivers will help them learn what is expected and how to react. 

Tips for couple alignment: 

  • If you're completing a program (like the Dr Golly Sleep Program) or even just researching different ideas make sure both caregivers complete the course or read the article 
  • If it's possible to complete research or courses together, even better!  This way you can discuss topics while they are fresh - both parents should be empowered with all the information
  • Talk openly and often about how you want to parent, the values you want to instill in your kids
  • Talk openly and often about what you don't want to do as parents, behaviors you have witnessed that you don't want to replicate  
  • Align on your strategies so your baby always gets a consistent message, for sleep training in particular this is incredibly important  e.g. remain consistent on sleepy words, settling techniques and the desired routine when you start to implement them 
  • Don't play the "Disneyland parent" - offering treats and undermining the rules you've set together 
  • Once a week have a "planning night" it's not as romantic as date night but maybe more beneficial for your relationship.  Meal plan for the week, work our what activities, workload you both have on, align on who is doing what

Parenting is the most intricate team sport there is - by aligning on your strategy, respecting each others views, engaging in the research or content, always being open to discussion and new ideas and planning together you'll find both your parenting ability and relationship will be stronger.

Itâ€™s crucial that parents of newborns seek help when needed and make life as simple as possible for themselves in the first few months of a babyâ€™s life. Go back to basics and try to slow life down where you can.

Some strategies include:

  • Online grocery shopping
  • Meal delivery services
  • Meal planning and diary planning
  • Asking for help from a relative, friend, or neighbor
  • Taking shifts overnight if possibleâ€”one parent goes to bed early, and if your baby settles early for the night, ensure you both head to bed too.
  • Getting out for fresh air and a walk every day
  • Inviting a friend over for a coffee if you feel itâ€™s too much to go out
  • Itâ€™s okay to say "no" to things
  • Resting when the baby sleeps
  • Engaging with friends or your new parent group
  • Seeking out support if you need help or are feeling down

Itâ€™s also important to remember how all this started. Create a space in the home where thereâ€™s no newborn influenceâ€”no nappies, wipes, toys, etc.â€”a place where you can feel like youâ€™re the only people in the world.

With all the focus on the baby and the sleep deprivation, remember that youâ€™re both doing an incredible job. Take time to acknowledge each other and remind yourselves that you are participating in the most magnificent, magical, and important process of your livesâ€”molding a child, nourishing them, and sharing your love.

When youâ€™re spending so much time smelling dirty nappies, itâ€™s important to pauseâ€”and smell the roses.

I have referred many families to sleep schools in the past and seen terrific results, but compared to those Iâ€™ve sent, I have stopped many more from attending. This is because many MBUs (mother-baby units) send a message to parents that there is a militant solution and that they canâ€™t achieve it without this. I firmly disagree with this.

We need to empower, not disempower parents. Manage your child according to their needs, within an age-appropriate, flexible routine framework. Not militant regimens.

Please note: Some mothers experience extreme emotional changes in the postnatal period, including psychosis and depression. These mothers may be admitted to a mental healthcare facility for new mothers, which is not the same thing as a â€˜sleep schoolâ€™ concept.

Normal adjustment, the Baby Blues, postnatal depression (PND), postnatal anxiety (PNA), or other mental illnesses can all occur after birth.

Being informed & knowing when to seek help is key.

For many mothers and fathers, having a new baby is a time of happiness and joy. However, even normal adjustment to parenting can bring a range of emotions.

In this section, Perinatal Psychiatrist Dr. Adaobi Udechuku talks through what is normal and what is:

  1. Postnatal Depression (PND)
  2. Postnatal Anxiety (PNA)
  3. Another mental illness

Postnatal Depression (PND) affects up to 1 in 7 mums and up to 1 in 10 dads after birth. Symptoms last longer than 2 weeks, and your ability to function is impaired.

Common symptoms of PND include:

  • A numb, sad, or low mood
  • Excessive crying
  • A loss of interest in enjoyable activities, including your baby
  • Having difficulty sleeping (not due to your baby waking) or excessive sleeping
  • Loss or increased appetite and/or weight loss or gain

Postnatal Anxiety (PNA) is thought to be more common than Postnatal Depression (PND). A recent study found that 1 in 5 women had at least one type of anxiety disorder during pregnancy or postpartum.

Common PNA symptoms vary and include:

  • Anxiety, fear, or worry that is difficult to control (e.g., about your babyâ€™s health, sleeping, or feeding)
  • Feeling irritable, tense, restless, or on edge
  • Increased heart rate or breathing, nausea, or the shakes
  • Difficulty falling asleep at night (including when your baby is asleep)
  • Excessive checking on your baby

Depression and anxiety symptoms often occur together.

A small proportion of mothers (1-2 per 1000 births) are affected by the rare but serious illness of Postpartum Psychosis (PPP). Therefore, it is important to seek help as soon as possible.

Symptoms include:

  • Elevated, irritable, or up-and-down moods
  • Increased or racing thoughts
  • Increased amounts of speech
  • A reduced need for sleep
  • Increase in activity
  • Disorganization
  • Hearing voices and/or having false beliefs or delusions
  • Thoughts of harm to yourself or your baby

Lesson Name: Which Parents are at Greater Risk of Mental Health Problems?
Lesson Content:
Factors that may increase your risk of PND, PNA, or PPP include:

  • A past history of depression, anxiety, or Bipolar Disorder
  • A family history of mental illness, especially PPP, Bipolar Disorder, or other mental illness related to childbirth
  • If you experienced your birth as traumatic
  • A lack of support, including from your partner
  • Stressful life events (e.g. moving, renovating, changing jobs, a loss of job, the death of a parent or grandparent)

If you think you are suffering from:

  • Postnatal Depression (PND)
  • Postnatal Anxiety (PNA)
  • Postpartum Psychosis (PPP)
  • Or if you have thoughts of harm to yourself or your baby

REMEMBER:

  1. Seeking help is essential.
  2. Help is available.

The good news is that with the right care, Postnatal Depression (PND), Postnatal Anxiety (PNA), and Postpartum Psychosis (PPP) can be treated, and you can recover.

Below is a contingency plan of what to do if your baby wakes early.

Under 5 months old
Power nap: If your baby has woken early (i.e., pre 6.15 am) and will not resettle, then a power nap can be used until 5 months old. A power nap is a small 15-minute nap ONLY to help get your baby through to their next nap time and keep their day on track. Allowing them to only have 15 minutes may seem cruel, but we want to avoid them falling into a very deep sleep, as this will decrease their drive to sleep, making their next nap harder to achieve.

So your morning might look something like this:
6 am - Wake up, unable to be resettled
7.15 am - Power nap
7.30 am - Wake baby up
9 am - Nap 1 back on track.

A power nap is only a temporary solution and should only be used for a few days in a row, as we donâ€™t want it to become a new habit.

Over 5 months old:
If your baby wakes early, try your best to stretch them out until as close to their normal nap time as possible. A little walk around the garden or playtime in a different room might help pass the time if they are more fussy and tired than usual because of the early wake-up.

Lesson Name: What to do if Your Baby is Cat-Napping
Lesson Content:
Please see more in our lessons in Chapter 1.3 - Routines for more information on resettling your baby if they are cat-napping.

At the morning nap

Under 5 months: If your baby has slept for 20-30 minutes, then resettle them for 30 minutes, then get them up at their wake-up time. They may need a power nap to help get them through to their lunchtime nap without getting completely overtired. A power nap is a small 15-minute nap ONLY to help get your baby through to their next nap time and keep their day on track. Allowing them to only have 15 minutes may seem cruel, but we want to avoid them falling into a very deep sleep, as this will decrease their drive to sleep, making their next nap harder to achieve.

i.e.:
9 am - Morning nap
9.30 am - Woke up, resettle for 30 mins but unable to go back to sleep
10 am - Up with a happy wake-up
11.15 am - 11.30 am - Power nap
12.30 pm - Nap 1 back on track.

Over 5 months: Resettle for 30 minutes and then try to stretch your baby until as close to their next nap time as possible. It's likely you'll have to put them down earlier for their next nap though to prevent them from getting overtired.

At the lunchtime nap:

  • If your baby has slept less than 40 minutes, then resettle them for 1 hour. If they are still awake, get them up for a 10-minute cuddle and top-up feed, then put them back down and try again. If they fall asleep again and itâ€™s close to their wake-up time, let them have an extra 20-30 minutes before waking them.
  • Slept less than 1.5 hours: Resettle them for 30-40 minutes, then get them up with a happy wake-up.
  • If your baby wakes and resettles multiple times in the first 1 hour after being put down, resettle them for 30-40 minutes before doing a happy wake-up if they are still awake.
  • Slept more than 1.5 hours: Go in and get them up with a happy wake-up and lots of praise on what a good sleep they had!

If your baby hasnâ€™t slept well during the day, then be sure to bring bedtime earlier, closer to 6 pm. Stretching out a baby for their evening bedtime when they are overtired is the worst thing to do.

Fussy day - What to do on a fussy or busy day when your baby just hasnâ€™t slept well:
Adjust bedtime and bring it earlier. An overtired baby who has been stretched out to their usual bedtime will just tend to have a more broken nightâ€™s sleep and wake earlier in the morning.

If your baby is on 2 naps, then bring dinner earlier too. A 4.30 pm dinner is fine to allow you to get some food into them before they become even more overtired, cranky, and less likely to eat. It will also give you more time to do a nice wind-down routine and get into bed earlier.

If your baby has completely refused their nap despite attempts to resettle them, get them up with a happy wake up. If your baby is under 5 months old then offer a Power Nap as per the routine for their age group (see Chapter 1.3 - Routines). If over 6 months then try to get your baby to as close to the next nap time as possible. However, realistically this can be tricky and you may have to put your baby down 30mins earlier than usual and this is ok.

Sickness is a common cause for baby sleep problems

This is more common with older babies than 4-16 weeks, but regularly in consultations I'll hear parents remark that their once â€˜excellent sleeperâ€™ has struggled to sleep ever since an episode of sickness, which threw everything off kilter. Itâ€™s incredibly common.

Beyond the stress of having a baby who is sick (don't underestimate how stressful this is when they are young), your hard-earned sleep routine suddenly evaporates as they require closer attention and TLC.

Never Sleep Train a Sick Baby

The routines in our program have a strong caveat present throughout â€” everything goes out the window if your baby is sick: never sleep train or attempt to re-settle a sick baby.

If your baby was capable of an excellent day/night routine prior to falling sick, they are equally capable of returning to it, once they fully recover.

Simple steps to return to normal sleep after sickness

TIP 1: Allow your baby to rest and recover

  • This means reduced activities, stimulation, and play.
  • Sleep boosts recovery, so allow longer day naps if they are happening or put them to bed earlier if they're showing lots of tired signs.
  • Always ensure your baby is not sleeping due to lethargy and severe illness â€“ if in doubt, consult your doctor immediately.
  • Assisted naps are absolutely allowed if your baby is unwell.

TIP 2: Try to maintain a similar routine with familiar steps

  • Like bath time or reading stories.
  • If routines or patterns break due to sickness, try to minimise the change where possible.

TIP 3: Hydration

  • Increase breastfeeds, an oral rehydration solution in a dropper is sometimes required to maintain fluid intake and a good number of wet nappies. Speak to your doctor or pharmacist about these.

TIP 4: Once your baby has fully recovered, rapidly return to normal

  • Expect them to adjust back to their previous routine within 2-3 days.
  • If you initially used elongated sleep training methods, you will not have to start from square one; you can quickly return to the previous normal.

REMEMBER: If you have a sick baby or if you are ever in doubt, always see your doctor to have them checked.

At this age, often bedtime refusal just means your baby just doesnâ€™t have quite enough sleep debt built up, so try stretching their awake time a little longer to see if that helps things. Keep in mind the suggested routine; however, remember that every baby is a bit different, so sometimes a little trial and error is needed.

Tip: ensure your baby is having a consistent wind-down routine at bedtime, as this will help teach them to anticipate bedtime and learn that it's almost time for sleep.

Eczema - or atopic dermatitis - causes dry, red and scaly skin - almost anywhere on the body.

Eczema is extremely itchy and is a relatively common contributor to unsettled infant behaviour.

If severe, the dry skin will eventually start to crack and bleed, leading to a risk of infection. 

Eczema commonly starts around 2 months of age, and often gets missed as it can resemble (normal) newborn acne. The key difference is that eczematous skin is very dry to touch, almost like sandpaper. When mild, most children will outgrow their eczema by the age of 5 years. Certain things can cause flares of eczema, like allergens (food, pet hair, pollen, etc), excessive heat, stress or having a cold. 

Eczema tends to occur in families, especially when there is a history of atopy - this means a tendency to sensitivity (eczema, asthma, allergy or hay-fever). If you had eczema, there is an 80% chance your child could be affected too. 

If eczema is essentially extreme dryness, the number one enemy of eczema is heat. 

Try to reduce the heat by removing a single layer (clothing or blanket) at all times, ensuring your baby never gets too cold, but prevent overheating. Natural fibre, breathable fabric clothing is preferable. Regular moisturising helps to return moisture to the dry skin and occasionally, medicated creams/ointments are needed too; discuss this with your childâ€™s doctor.
