Adjusting to the daylight savings time change can be a huge stress for some families and itâ€™s pretty common to be concerned that your baby's sleep will be impacted in a big way. 


There are a couple of ways to go about helping them adjust to the change: 

Go With The Flow 

The first option is to just go with the flow on the day of the change and adjust their schedule accordingly. This can work well for newborns as they tend to be a bit more flexible and are happier to sleep on the go to catch up (ie. in the pram, carrier, car seat, etc). However, you may need to pop them to bed a little earlier for a couple of days to help with the transition, or give them an extra nap. If your baby is established in a routine and over 6 weeks old then try to stay consistent with your routine. 

Staggered transition

The second option is to slowly transition your baby in the week prior to the time change. This is helpful if you have a baby over 6 weeks old and they are quite sensitive to changes in their routine. Know that it can be normal for babies to have a couple of days where their routine might be a little bit off, but staying consistent will help them adjust quickly to the change.  See below on how to slowly transition them.

Daylight savings commencing:

Â·  Based on a 7am wake up, on Monday and Tuesday wake your baby at 6.45am and move everything forward by 15mins, including feeds and naps.

Â·  On Wednesday/Thursday, move everything forward 30 mins, including feeds and naps.

Â·  On Friday move everything forward 45mins (wake at 6.15am).

Â·  On Saturday move everything forward by 1hr (wake your baby 6am).

Â·  Then on Sunday when the clocks have moved forward your baby will automatically be back to waking at 7am.

Daylight savings ending:

Â·  Based on a 7am wake up, on Monday and Tuesday wake your baby at 7.15am and move everything back by 15mins, including feeds and naps.

Â·  On Wednesday/Thursday, move everything back 30 mins, including feeds and naps.

Â·  On Friday move everything back by 45mins (wake at 7.45am).

Â·  On Saturday move everything back by 1hr (wake your baby 8am).

Â·  Of course, your baby may not naturally sleep until 8am and if this is the case then offer a power nap for 15mins to help get them to the later nap time.

Â·  Then on Sunday when the clocks have moved back your baby will automatically be back to waking at 7am.


General daylight savings tips:

  • Ensure your babyâ€™s sleep environment is nice and dark, as dark as possible. This will help their body clock adjust and help stop early morning waking from sunlight creeping in. It will also help them go to sleep at bedtime by promoting their melatonin production while it is still light outside.
  • Crank that white noise to help drown out the birds waking for the day.
  • Continue the same bedtime routine pre and post daylight savings as your little one is familiar with this.
  • Get outside in the natural sunlight in the afternoon if possible. This natural light burst helps melatonin production of an evening.

Lesson Name: Parents Worried About the â€˜4 Month Sleep Regressionâ€™
Lesson Content:
Please Note: 

1. If your baby is only 4 weeks and you're just starting the program skip this for now

2. If your baby is 12 weeks or older all this information below is in a publicly available blog, please read and feel free to share it with every family in your parents group - I want everyone moving into the Big Baby 4-8 month Sleep Program to feel empowered about this next chapter and all parents to be excited by their babies progress.


Are you worried about the "4 month sleep regression"?

In my paediatric practice, I commonly see the perfectly happy, settled baby who is sleeping beautifully overnight â€“ but then reaches 4 months of age and the wheels seem to fall off.

Some speak of the4-month sleep regression, like itâ€™s some cruel rite of passage that all parents must simply endure. Iâ€™m here to tell you itâ€™s not.

When do baby sleep regressions happen?

Search google and youâ€™ll find any number of ages where sleep regressions are likely to occur 4 months, 6 months, 8 months, 18 monthsâ€¦


















The truth is â€“ there is no such thing as a 4-month sleep regression.

Yes you heard me, whether itâ€™s 4-6-12-18 months.  While sleep deterioration can occur from time to time there is always something driving the unsettled behaviour â€“ itâ€™s not something you have to suffer through, itâ€™s an opportunity for us to help our babies.

It infuriates me when parents are advised that this is a real thing, this deterioration of the feed/sleep routine youâ€™ve worked so tirelessly to achieve.

â€œSleep regressionsâ€ traditionally describe a deterioration of a baby who was otherwise settled and sleeping well, that suddenly:

  • has trouble self-settling
  • wonâ€™t Fall Asleep independently
  • can no longer link sleep cycles
  • is taking frequent short naps and feeds
  • becomes increasingly fussy overnight
  • has difficulty falling asleep
  • is generally â€œfighting sleepâ€
  • decreased total sleep across a 24 hour period

There is absolutely NO necessity for babies to become unsettled and have sleep problems

at 4 months of age and there isdefinitelyNO developmental â€˜leapâ€™ that explains this collapsing of a beautiful overnight routine (see my critique of The Wonder Weeks).

4 months is a beautiful age â€“ it should not be feared â€“itâ€™s one of my favourite developmental stages â€“ where babies begin to babble with early verbal communication, they respond excitedly to play and they reach out to touch your face or grab at toys.

That doesnâ€™t sound like regression to me!

What causes baby sleep â€œregressionsâ€?

Itâ€™s not lost on me Iâ€™m still using the word regression here but understanding â€œregressionsâ€ is similar to my entire philosophy as a paediatrician and specialist in unsettled babies and baby sleepâ€¦

â€¦we always need to look for the cause of the unsettled behaviour.

A number of factors can cause a baby or childâ€™s sleep patterns to change or deteriorate at any age

  1. A growth spurt which will make your baby hungrier
  2. Developmental changes (both physical and cognitive)
    â€“ these will be different for every baby/child (donâ€™t follow an app to tell you when your baby is having a â€œLEAPâ€ or a developmental change!!) always watch your baby
  3. Illness (where hydration & comfort become the focus), see 
  4. Discomfort: itchy tags, being too hot or cold/ or uncontrolled eczema are the most common things I see
  5. Disruptions in routines: like starting daycare or a new sibling arriving
  6. Changes to room environment: unswaddling, travel, moving to own room, big bed etc.
  7. Teething pain: although this is short lived
  8. Separation anxiety which may start around the 10-12 month mark
  9. As your baby progresses into the toddler years nightmare and night terrors may play a role
  10. Age appropriate day sleep or sleep schedule: this is a huge one.  Our babies and toddler sleep patterns and requirements change regularly and their day sleep needs to adjust, â€“ the sleep program includes age appropriate routines for all age groups Toddler sleep patterns

When you understand the changes happening at any age â€“ you get a clearer idea of how to manage things correctly and overcome them.

A few small changes are often all that is required for you one step closer to having your baby truly sleep through the night, from 7pm to 7am.

What happens to babies at 4 months?

Around the 4 month mark will signify major developmental changes for babies â€“ remember this timing will be different for every child.

Sleep cycles will change here, becoming more adult-like, with less time in deep, REM-sleep and more time in light sleep which can make linking their next sleep cycle problematic.

This coincides with a really big growth spurt, both physically and cognitively.

With a growing body and growing mind,babies become far more alert to their surroundings.

  • Some babies might get bored with feeding after 10 minutes
  • they might start to dislike being placed backwards in a car-seat or stroller,
  • they may even start to talk to themselves or play with their hands when they were previously sleeping soundly.

Their growing body will often learn to roll during this period â€“ which will mean more activity and that you will no longer be able to swaddle them for sleeps, their little cocoon will go â€“ a huge change to their sleep environment! (NB: There are lots of tips in the sleep program to manage  un-swaddling.)

Donâ€™t be disheartened by these changes â€“they represent brilliant developmental progression!

The exact opposite of regression; these changes should be celebrated.

But to do all this new stuff, your baby is going to require a lot more energy.


The only way to get more energy is to eat more food, to take in more calories.

The amount of energy a baby can get from milk every feed is limited by the size of their stomach, meaning the only way to give them more energy through milk is to add another feed, and the only time available to do this is overnight.

Introducing solids around the four-month mark has a number of benefits.

  1. Firstly, it can take several weeks of practice before your baby is confidently taking decent volumes of solids at each meal, meaning it could be a while before theyâ€™re taking in enough calories to provide adequate energy to last the night.
  2. Secondly â€“ international allergy guidelines point to strong evidence that we can reduce the lifetime risk of allergies by introducing common allergens (triggers) in a window between 4 to 6 months.  Delaying solids has the potential to increase the chances of having allergies to things like nuts, eggs or fish.

When is my baby ready to start solids?

Youâ€™ll know itâ€™s time to start introducing solid foods because your baby will start to tell you!

Many parents will delay starting solids thinking their child needs to be sitting independently but the truth is there are many signs of solids readiness and they only need head control not independent sitting to kick off.

Things to look out for include:

  • more head control,
  • increased saliva production (drooling),
  • better oro-motor coordination (lessening of newborn tongue-thrust),
  • relaxing of the gag reflex,
  • tracking of your mouth when you eat solids in front of them
  • and the fine and gross motor skills of bringing objects across their midline and toward their mouth.

Remember at this age solids should add to â€“ not replace â€“ milk feeds.

Breastmilk, formula, or a mix of the two are still the primary source of nutrition for your baby.

Why is tummy time important for minimising the 4 month â€œsleep regressionâ€?

Your baby learning to roll is a major milestone and incredibly important for development, celebrate, donâ€™t lament this.

Tummy time is really important for 2 key reasons:

  1. Getting stuck in the cot on their tummy
    â€“ If your baby has say learnt to roll back to front and is now sleeping unswaddled we need to teach them to roll front to back so they can settle themselves in their cot and not get â€œstuckâ€ on their tummy
  2. Neck control for starting solids
    â€“ Tummy time will help strengthen everything and increase readiness for solids â€“ so you can get them those extra calories they are craving

Tips for managing â€œBaby Sleep Regressionsâ€:

  1. Understand what is driving the unsettled behaviour and never dismiss it as a â€œLEAPâ€ or something that canâ€™t be resolved
  2. Room environment: youâ€™ll find all this tips for every age group in the program
  3. Age appropriate day sleep & a consistent bedtime routine â€“ youâ€™ll find these in the program
  4. Good sleep habits and hygiene: strong foundations are key
  5. Regardless of the Sleep training method you shoes â€“ Consistency patience and persistence are key

Will all babies have â€œsleep regressionsâ€?

No, research has shown that there is significant variation in infant sleep â€“ not all babies will go through this.  Some babies may have no detectable sleep changes at 4 months while some may see a deterioration around this age (see all the reasons listed above).

In my experience when parents are empowered with the knowledge to always look for what is driving the unsettled behaviour will approach the problem looking for solutions rather than despair that this is a period they just have to suffer through.

Changing the vernacular around â€œregressionsâ€

If we start to look at regressions asdevelopmental progressionsit can start to change the way we look at and approach these topics.

Start asking yourself:

  • What has changed in my baby lately?
  • What new things are they doing?
  • What are the developmental milestones in your babyâ€™s age category
  • What has changed in my babyâ€™s sleep environment?
  • Are they on an age appropriate sleep routine?
  • What might these changes mean? E.g. they are hungrier, transitioning out of a swaddle etc.
  • What can I do to support my baby through these changes?

Remember: 

  • There is always something driving the unsettled behaviour.
  • What has traditionally been described as a regression is actually a progression.
  • As they grow and develop, itâ€™s up to us as parents to observe our babies and better understand what they need from us.

Parents â€“ you got this!

If your baby is still feeding overnight, this can contribute to more urinating overnight and heavier, leaky nappies. Newborns are obligate nose breathers, meaning they primarily breathe through their noses! 

Most parents are shocked that babies donâ€™t breathe through their mouths until they are closer to 12 months â€“ thatâ€™s why nasal congestion can be really concerning, especially when it impacts feeding.

Due to the nasal passages being small and therefore prone to congestion, it can quickly impact feeding and lead to general unsettledness and sleep disturbances.

Causes of congestion

Colds and respiratory infections:
Newborns have developing immune systems, making them susceptible to colds and respiratory infections.
This can lead to an increase in mucous production and congestion, making it harder for your baby to breathe nasally.

Environmental factors:
Dust, pet dander, and other allergens in the air can irritate your babyâ€™s nose, leading to congestion.

Dry air:
Dry air can irritate your babyâ€™s nose, leading to congestion. This is especially common during the winter months when heating systems are in use.

How to safely clear a newbornâ€™s congested nose

You can clear a newbornâ€™s congested nose to help your baby breathe, using gentle and safe techniques. Here are my recommendations:

Salt water nose drops:
Saline drops can help loosen the mucus in your babyâ€™s nose, making it easier to clear â€“ you can use specialised drops or just plain old saline solution from the chemist and use a small syringe to drop them in.
Lay your baby on their back and gently squeeze a few drops of saline solution into each nostril.
Wait for a few moments, and then use a bulb syringe to suction out the loosened mucus.
Once they are bigger you can use saline sprays.

Bulb syringe suction:
A bulb syringe can be used to suction out the mucus from your babyâ€™s nose.
Squeeze the bulb, gently insert the tip into your babyâ€™s nostril, create a good seal and release the bulb to deliver suction.
Be careful not to insert the syringe too far into your babyâ€™s nose or suction too forcefully.

I personally find these arenâ€™t as effective as nasal aspirators (see below) but they are better than nothing.

NOTE: Snot sucking will be one of the most disgustingly enjoyable things youâ€™ll do as a parent! 

Nasal aspirators â€“ AKA SNOT SUCKERS!

These devices help by removing excess mucus from your babyâ€™s nose and use prolonged suction to clear the nasal passages.
There are electric versions or ones where you use your own mouth to literally â€˜suck the snotâ€™ out of the noseâ€¦if youâ€™re like me, youâ€™ll like the one that uses your own mouth for better control, but the electric ones are great too.

As a paediatrician, I canâ€™t recommend specific pharmaceuticals or medical devices but every family with a baby needs saline and a snot sucking aspirator of some description in their baby kit. 

If your baby is congested, I recommend you use saline and an aspirator before every feed and before you put them down to sleep.
